Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KNX-7CX1-F0B4-8418-00000-00100 top Start-ups A-D2016-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:55ZLexisNexis100 top Start-ups A-DAkita

Akita is a software solution that provides businesses with insight into their customer relationships by connecting the cloud-based software applications that businesses use, in order to improve sales and reduce customer attrition.

“Our customer success platform helps Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) companies address their number one challenge: how to retain existing customers and convince them to spend more,” says co-founder Barry Devon.

“We’re currently working closely with some of Ireland’s most innovative SaaS businesses, but Akita’s road from idea to promising start-up has taken many months and even more miles.”

Founded in 2013 by American expat Clay Smith, Akita graduated from the NDRC’s Launchpad accelerator with the goal of helping companies better understand their customers. Strengthened by the addition of Barry Devon as co-founder and head of customer acquisition, Akita set its sights on the emerging customer success industry.

To keep costs low while building Akita’s new offering, Smith and Sandra Pender (his fiancée and founding team member) spent the next 18 months living the life of “digital nomads”.

While Devon remained in Dublin building Akita’s local customer base, Smith and Pender worked remotely from Mexico, Hawaii, France, Cork and most recently, Tallinn in Estonia.

“Akita’s early mission – to help companies better understand their customers – has never wavered and lays the foundation for our innovative new offering,” says Devon. “Though it has taken a winding path, we’re confident that Akita is poised to become a leader in the exploding customer success industry.”

Amryt Pharma

Amryt Pharma is a specialty pharmaceutical company focused on developing and delivering innovative new treatments to help improve the lives of patients with rare and orphan diseases. Established last year, the Dublin-headquartered company has already acquired two companies, secured European approval for its lead product Episalvan for treating minor wounds, and listed on the Irish and British stock exchanges.

Focused on developing best-in-class orphan or rare disease treatments, Amryt is developing a new epidermolysis bullosa (EB) treatment, a rare and distressing genetic skin disorder affecting young children for which there is currently no treatment. Analysts’ estimates suggest this could unlock a $1 billion market for Amryt.

Amryt’s founder and chief executive Joe Wiley was a doctor before holding senior positions as medical director of Astellas and European head of Sofinnova Ventures. Wiley is an industry veteran, having previously backed Opsona and Innocoll.

“Ireland is a great place to establish a new internationally focused business like Amryt. It has a well-educated and entrepreneurial workforce, a favourable funding environment, easy access to most countries and, post-Brexit, Malta and Ireland will be the EU’s only English speaking countries,” says Wiley.

Amryt’s funding involved a reverse takeover of a quoted cash shell, as well as raising £10 million. Some of this will fund phase III trials on Episalvan as a treatment for EB, which could allow Amryt to submit Episalvan for EU and US approval.

In the near-term, the company is building revenue by selling its Imlan skincare product.

Anchorlily

Anchorlily is a start-up that creates multi-sensory products for people with dementia. Its first product is a “life blanket” which provides comfort to users by capturing their important life memories in images. “Our mission is to promote their well-being, maintain connections to their identity and provide opportunities for engagement within their world,” founder Catherine Daly, an occupational therapist, says.

“We have encountered great support through the local enterprise offices, start-up networks and through Enterprise Ireland’s New Frontiers programme. This mixture of funding and mentoring enabled us to launch our first product after we completed the programme in 2016.”

Since then, Anchorlily has attracted private investment and is pursuing strategic partnerships in Britain for its next range of products. “We are basing ourselves at the Synergy centre in IT Tallaght, which provides an environment where we meet other entrepreneurs, mentors and have ready access to advice and support. We are also staying engaged with the range of state-funded enterprise supports that are available,” Daly says.

Anchorlily plans to expand its operations, focusing on Ireland initially and then expanding outwards. Its plan is to launch a new product – a protective bed bumper – in the near future and it is looking for further funding to fund expansion.

“There are 46.8 million worldwide living with dementia and this is set to treble by 2050,” says Daly. “We want to provide products that will help people live well with the condition and stay connected to their identity, family and friends.”

AQMetrics

AQMetrics is a regulatory risk management and compliance software company that utilises the latest cloud computing and big data analytics technology to save clients both time and money in navigating their regulatory environment.

The company was founded by Geraldine Gibson in 2012 with a team experienced in regulatory risk and compliance solutions.

Before spearheading AQMetrics, Gibson worked for seven years as head of professional services at Norkom Technologies prior to its sale for €217 million to the defence and security giant, BAE systems.

In February, the company concluded a funding round that raised $3.25 with backing from companies including Bluff Point Associates, a Connecticut-based private equity firm, Enterprise Ireland and Irish venture capital firm Frontline Ventures.

“There is a very clear gap in the market for what we do,” Gibson says. “Our recent fundraising will allow us to scale and expand our team.”

AQMetrics has helped companies like InterTrust navigate cross-border compliance and meet regulatory reporting requirements in multiple jurisdictions.

The company recently opened a New York office, where it plans to expand and diversify its client base of alternative investment management and broker companies. “Regulation can’t be escaped. We are targeting a multibillion-dollar market,” says Gibson.

Arralis

Tech start-up Arralis provides expertise in micro and millimetre-wave technology, partnering with other technology providers to build products which are used not only globally but also in space.

The company was founded at the end of 2013, when there was a shift in focus from microwaves to very high-frequency millimetre waves.

“Companies had no choice but to move out of microwaves,” says co-founder Barry Lunn. “No one was doing millimetre waves at scale, so we saw an opportunity there to be ready for that roll-out.”

Lunn and co-founder Mike Gleaves worked together for ten years previously in another company before setting up Arralis. After working on the other company’s products for a year, a seed round at the end of 2014 allowed them to focus on their own product.

The company is unusual in that its business is 100 per cent international.

“Because of the nature of what we do, there’s no market in Ireland,” says Lunn. “We provide products for people working on drones or space stations or building wireless networks – that’s not happening here.”

With business in the US and Asia as well as in Europe, Lunn says they have “lots of air miles clocked up”.

Their first customer in Europe for their own product was the European Space Agency. “That was huge,” says Lunn. “They’re a great reference customer.”

Enterprise Ireland was essential to bringing the ESA on board as a customer. “They guided us through the process and brought the right people to the table.”

The company is actively involved in fundraising and Lunn says they are “constantly adding people”. With the focus at the moment on the US and Asia, “the ambition is to grow something big”.

BetterExaminations.ie

BetterExaminations.ie is the initiative of third-year Trinity College Dublin students James Eggers and Daniel Hobbs. Their site offers quick and easy access for secondary school students to Junior Certificate and Leaving Certificate exam papers.

“When I was in school, I found the existing system for accessing exam papers really hard to use” says Eggers. “Using it every day, it becomes fairly tiresome, so I decided to create a better version.”

The resulting site proved extremely popular among his classmates, saving them time and streamlining their study, he says.

Going on to study computer science at Trinity, he met BESS student Hobbs, and the two joined forces in September 2015 to create the business. “He takes care of the business side and I do the nerdy stuff,” laughs Eggers.

The pair began to sell to schools, including the Institute of Education, St Michael’s and Blackrock College, and the profits began rolling in. “Word of mouth has been really important in increasing exposure,” says Eggers. “The site now has over 65,000 users and we have developed two apps – one for iPhones and one for Android.”

This year Eggers’ and Hobbs’ company is taking part in LaunchBox 2016, Trinity’s three-month accelerator programme for start-ups. Their next step is to introduce BetterExaminations for universities, which will make it easier for universities to upload papers and for students to search and download papers. They also plan to launch the BetterExaminations Teacher Awards, which will recognise teachers around Ireland for contribution to student life both inside and outside the classroom.

“Balancing the website with a full-time degree can be hard,” admits Eggers. “We mostly work on it in the evenings, but the aim is to work on it full time once we graduate.”

BEUTiFi

If you’re trying to find a restaurant, you turn to JustEat or Yelp. If you’re looking for a hotel or hostel, there’s Booking.com – but if you’re trying to find a hair or beauty salon, where do you turn? BEUTiFi.com was created to fill this gap, making it simpler and more convenient to discover salons and book appointments.

The site is essentially a subscription-based online platform connecting salons and professionals with consumers. Founder Richard Spence explains how the site provides a service to businesses and clients alike.

“Salons receive new clients which they go on to retain; and we improve their efficiency by helping them use some of the 35 per cent empty capacity they currently have, increasing their revenues and improving their online presence. We offer consumers informed choice, peer reviews, the best prices and offers all in one place, the ability to book online in real time 24/7 and rewards for making bookings.

“It’s crazy to think that in this day and age, less than 30 per cent of salons have an online presence,” Spence says. “We are moving a traditionally very offline industry online.”

BEUTiFi.com went live in Ireland in summer 2015 and has received funding from NDRC and Enterprise Ireland. It was runner-up in the Bolton Trust Innovation Awards and recently won a place on Google’s Adopt a Start-up programme.

The site now has over 1,700 salon customers, including 1,000 customers in Britain through the purchase of a competitor called SalonAddict.

“We have our sights set on building a €100 million plus business by becoming a leading global online marketing platform for the hair and beauty sectors and the ‘go to’ discovery and booking portal for consumers,” says Spence.

Boost Bites

Healthy snack company Boost Bites produces a range of energy-boosting raw snacks. Gluten free, dairy free and vegan, they tick all the “clean eating” boxes.

Boost Bites founder Cliona Hegarty previously worked as a teacher for over six years, before finding herself in the food industry. She is passionate about healthy food and helping people achieve a balanced lifestyle.

With support in the form of mentoring and funding from Dublin BIC, Enterprise Ireland and Dublin City Local Enterprise Office, Boost Bites has gone from strength to strength. “I have a bit more breathing space now, and I’m able to share responsibilities,” Hegarty says. “My team has grown to four people and I feel very proud of what we have achieved so far.

“Start-ups are like a rollercoaster ride: you climb to the top of multiple challenges on a daily basis, which can seem somewhat overwhelming, but the freefalls down with every small success is what keeps you energised – that and my many packets of Boost Bites! The thrill of seeing my products on shelves will never get old.”

The plan for 2016 is to scale the business. Boost Bites’s products have recently secured a listing abroad, so export arrangements are in the works. Hegarty says she is lucky to be riding the wave of the health and wellness sector.

“People are prioritising their health and demanding genuinely healthy products, however, they don’t want to compromise on the taste,” she says. “My mission from day one was to disrupt the snacking industry with genuinely healthy and truly tasty wholefood snacks and so far so good.”

BuilderEngine

BuilderEngine is a cloud website builder for creating smarter websites. It offers accessible tools which make creating websites easier, regardless of the creator’s skill level or experience. The platform currently has over 130,000 users, with more than 90,000 joining in the last six months.

The team consists of five people, led by founder Keith Killilea. He previously worked in games development, and his background in the website development industry stretches back to 1997.

“A few years ago, I decided to take a break from the industry and looked in detail at the web engines,” says Killilea.

“I was shocked at the state of all of them, and the gap for a fully developed web engine for both new users and professionals was clear to me.

“Setting up in Ireland is a straightforward process, and while there can be improvements with less red tape, it is on the right path.

“We have self-funded the start-up with side projects and early investors, and now we are looking to secure a seed round to allow the business to expand faster.

“The future of BuilderEngine is to become the leading platform globally in the cloud for SME websites, including start-ups which want to prototype complicated sites within minutes,” he says.

“We want to power the future generation of websites across the world by giving non-designers and professionals the right tools to create complicated websites with ease, offering them features which match the professionals’.”

Buymie

Buymie is an on-demand grocery delivery service. It allows users to order grocery and household items from their favourite local stores via an app, and organises for them to be delivered in as little as one hour by a personal picker.

The start-up, which was founded in 2015 by Devan Hughes and Artavazd Sokhikyan and launched in Dublin in February of this year, has generated over 4,000 downloads in the first six months.

“Starting Buymie has been a rollercoaster from the get go,” says Hughes. “Our mission is to transform the way people view grocery shopping and allow customers to get whatever they need whenever they need it.

“We have a great team with a really diverse background, from data science in academia, to software development and cloud computing for Fortune 500 companies. There is a thriving start-up community in Ireland and it’s also incredibly cheap to get up and running as there are so many programmes that provide support and subsidised services for anything from advertising to server costs.”

Raising funding, however, has been a challenge for the start-up. “We still have a very small pool of investors, but it is growing,” says Hughes. “After raising initial funding from friends and family, we were nominated as a high-potential start-up with Enterprise Ireland, which gave us access to additional pre-seed funding and introductions to angel investors. We’re right in the middle of a new large funding round to help us expand our operation in Ireland and enter the British market.”

Carefolk

Carefolk.com is a Cork-based e-health start-up founded in 2016 by developers and entrepreneurs Owen O’Doherty and Shane McCarthy. O’Doherty’s mother suffered from Parkinson’s Disease and, surprised at how poor technical solutions were for the caring families and homecare companies, he built out the first version of Carefolk. This won the UCC Entrepreneur of the Year 2015, and Microsoft Gold Medal for .Net project of year.

“Whether you are looking after a child with autism or a partner or parent with dementia, providing ongoing care is not easy,” says O’Doherty. “The average length of care is seven years, the practicalities are endless and it can become quite isolating. To make matters more difficult, most are ‘accidental carers’ and have received no training. At Carefolk, we provide the tools and supports to make the lives of those who provide care better.”

Carefolk is developing two complementary web and mobile products. Carefolk Family allows for the easy co-ordination of care between family members, as well as homecare professionals. Carefolk Pro is a full management suite for care professionals and homecare companies, which reduces their cost base through the automation of business processes.

Although it is early days, Carefolk has global ambitions. “We will continue to innovate, build out our smart creative team and develop a global user base and brand based on products that help and inspire people,” says O’Doherty. “We are working towards building an IoT [internet of things] integrated care system.”

ChangeX

ChangeX is a non-profit online platform which supports local community initiatives, providing funding and information to help social entrepreneurs realise their ideas. The platform connects like-minded people and allows them to organise activities and build teams of volunteers. Some of the movements featured on the site include CoderDojo, Fighting Words and FoodCloud.

Since the site was launched in 2014, it has had little trouble attracting investors, despite being a not-for-profit organisation, raising over €400,000 during its first year. Early investors included Ben & Jerry co-founder Jerry Greenfield, Storyful founder Mark Little and businessman Dermot Desmond.

Change X has run various campaigns to encourage individuals to engage in their communities and put their ideas into action, like last year’s ChangeX100. “People are looking for more purpose and meaningful work, but it can be difficult to find the right opportunities,” says founder and chief executive Paul O’Hara. “That’s where ChangeX comes in – we can do a much better job at it, but we have a start.

“We want to connect the world’s best social innovations with growing numbers of people in local communities who want to make things better,” he says.

“Our next step is to continue growing in Ireland, experiment with international expansion – starting in the twin cities of Minneapolis and St Paul in the US from September – and to solidify our business model for sustainable growth.

“The ChangeX model can work anywhere, and our ambition is to be the number one international platform for social change. Our philosophy is: make it easy for people to do the right thing, and many will.”

Code Institute

Code Institute delivers full stack web development courses, both in class and mentored online, where students learn the skills required to kick-start a career in web and application development from accredited industry-validated coding courses that are reviewed by big tech companies including PayPal, Accenture and Morgan McKinley.

With a rapidly growing ICT skills gap and current academic methods, such as four-year computer science degrees failing to fill the talent pipeline with ‘plug-and-play’ industry ready developers, Code Institute developed an intensive coding bootcamp.

It produces industry-ready coders in as little as 12 weeks that employers can easily identify.

Code Institute secured €500,000 syndicated investment from Kernel Capital and Enterprise Ireland, which is enabling it to expand its reach in existing European markets and to create a suite of future courses and develop its current syllabus.

“The start-up world is incredibly fast-paced, but Ireland is a supportive incubator for all things tech. In one year, Code Institute has grown in staff, moved premises and expanded into new territories abroad,” says Rory Toal, digital marketing executive at Code Institute.

It currently partners with Learning People in Britain, and hopes to expand to four more territories by the end of 2016.

Child Paths

Dublin-based start-up Child Paths has developed an app which allows parents an insight into what their children do during their days in childcare facilities.

“I came up with the idea back in 2012 when my daughter had just moved from one childcare facility to another one,” says founder Ciaran Flynn. “At that point, I didn’t know much about childcare; like many parents, I thought it was just like a babysitting service, but I did some research and found out that that couldn’t be further from the truth.”

Flynn developed the idea over two years, launching Child Paths in September 2014.

“The first year was about validating the idea, then we took on our business development manager Robbie Carey and started focusing more on product development and customer service,” he says.

He explains how the app works. “Childcare facilities currently capture everything with pen and paper, but our software allows them to do that quicker and more efficiently and communicate this with parents.”

Child Paths is active in different facilities from Galway to Kerry, and has had interest from the US in the product. “Researchers liked our product because the focus was on the child’s development,” says Flynn.

“In the future, we’re looking at bringing this software to primary schools,” says Flynn. “It will work along the same lines, trying to highlight and showcase what children do in school for parents so they can support their child’s development at home.”

CleverBooks

Albert Einstein once said: “If you want your children to be intelligent, read them fairy tales. If you want them to be more intelligent, read them more fairy tales.” CleverBooks is built on this philosophy, producing sets of personalised educative stories where every child is the main character of the story.

Founder Darya Yegorina is a firm believer in the power of fairy tales. The idea for CleverBooks came from the stories her husband used to tell to their child, which she adapted to facilitate eating habits and make sure she was brushing her teeth daily.

“Fairy tales, in general, help kids to understand the world and adapt,” she says. “So why not use the fairy tales where the kids are the main characters? This helps them to get more involved in the story, realise their own behaviour in some way and also see the positive outcome of doing things differently.”

In each personalised story, the child plays a positive character.

“He or she is trying to understand things, makes mistakes, but understands and realises, apologises when he or she feels guilty and always becomes smarter and learns from his mistakes,” says Yegorina.

The creative team has developed different stories which cover topics to help parents, including the importance of brushing teeth, helping parents, eating vegetables, keeping bedrooms clean and in order, being honest, sharing with friends, and the dangers of eating too many sweets.

The self-funded company currently produces books for retail, as well as a self-service option for book-creating online. The start-up was one of 15 Irish companies shortlisted in Virgin Media’s Voom pitch-a-thon in London this year.

Cogni

Dublin-based start-up Cogni acts as a smartphone banking service for businesses. “There has been a fundamental shift in the small and micro-business world,” says founder Archie Ravishankar. “They no longer operate the way they operated 20 years ago because advances in technology and easier access to global markets mean that small businesses now trade without borders.”

Ravishankar, an Australian native, chose to establish the fintech company in Ireland in order to access the single European market. Across the EU, the freelance economy is the fastest growing group in the market: it has seen growth of over 45 per cent in the past ten years and now employs more than nine million people. Companies dealing with this economy have to manage vendors, suppliers, contractors and employees in multiple locations which generates large volumes of complex data.

“Traditional banks have failed to provide significant business value beyond their basic one-size-fits-all banking solution for these businesses,” says Ravishankar.

“Cogni is addressing this underserved, dynamic market by providing business banking that is faster, cheaper and more relevant to their individual business needs.”

The start-up allows companies to create a British and Sepa bank account in less than 15 minutes for any business in Europe, offering a single account that manages multiple currencies with an integrated payment solution to help businesses reduce cross-border currency complexities.

“Banking should not just be a utility, it should be something which helps and supports a business,” says Ravishankar. “It should give insight and understanding, support growth and be delivered through on-demand mediums which people use today for all their other activities.”

Cohort

Dublin-based start-up Cohort is a service which allows users and companies to leverage their networks better. Serial entrepreneur Eamon Leonard plans to launch the start-up, which is his fifth business, this month. Leonard previously co-founded Orchestra, a start-up which was sold to Engine Yard in a multimillion-euro deal in 2011. He has assembled eight angel investors to back his new business.

The rest of Cohort’s small team is made up of Eoin Hurrell, who joined the company as data lead from Aon; Brendan Hastings, who previously worked with Paddy Power, who is the start-up’s design lead; and developer Alex Kirwan.

Cohort works by building on the networks people already have in order to connect them to the people they need.

“We look at, for example, how people know each other on Twitter, who they have in common, friends of friends, what skills they have based on their profile, what they talk about and who they talk about it to,” says Leonard.

“We have the guts of ten or 20 years of people putting up information about themselves online,” Leonard says. “You have relationships fragmented across social networks, email, phone lists, laptops, other places. There isn’t a single place where your relationships are quantified and you can understand the potential that sits in there. I see this as a massive missed opportunity.”

Cortechs

After graduating from UCC with a BSc in neuroscience and a PhD in neuropathology, Áine Behan went on to research and lecture at the Royal College of Surgeons Ireland. With ten years’ postdoctoral experience in preclinical research, she felt that there were many areas of science and technology that had not yet made a commercial leap, with brainwave sensing technology being one of them.

Behan’s expertise lies in the effects of stresses – such as drugs – on mental health and neurodegenerative disease.

She founded Cortechs, a company that uses neuroscience, brainwave technology and gaming to improve attention deficit behaviours in children and adults.

It currently offers a mobile game for iOS and Android called Zip and the Misty Mountain, which aims to improve focus in six to 12-year-olds.

Cortechs uses Neurofeedback, which retrains the way brainwaves respond and can improve focus. In the Zip game, the more focused a child is, the more rewards they get within the game. Parents receive digestible and actionable feedback from the game on what their child has learned and improvements in their attention behaviour.

Early investors in Cortechs include Enterprise Ireland and the NDRC Catalyst programme. It has also received EU funding from the European Commission. The company expects to expand in the EU and into the US and Middle East.

Couture Intel

Adare native and founder of Couture Intel, Maria Phillips moved to Australia after working in the banking sector in Dublin for over ten years. Finding herself in a lucrative job with the Queensland government which gave her 60 holiday days a year, Phillips began to travel extensively throughout Asia.

“I went everywhere: China, Hong Kong, Japan, you name it,” says Phillips. “And as I was travelling, I was shopping. With my new job, I was able to buy more luxury items, but I still wanted the best price, so I kept a spreadsheet as I went with price comparisons.

“A lot of my friends in Australia were doing the same thing and they asked me to help them get better deals. So they’d tell me the products they wanted and I’d do them up a spreadsheet.”

Returning to Ireland in 2015, Phillips discussed making her Excel-based project a viable business, with her friend and web developer/engineer Niall Collins. He saw the potential in the idea, and together the two founded Couture Intel.

“We were lucky in that we didn’t need to look for funding to set up the company – it was all about the idea,” says Phillips. “We took part in Bank of Ireland’s Startlab incubator project in January in Galway which was great because it introduced us to more established companies who were able to give us really valuable feedback.”

Couture Intel is currently reaching out to retailers and anticipates bringing their first customer on board within the next two months. And the future? “We’re looking at some London and Dublin incubators at the moment,” says Phillips. “But we plan to focus on a small number of customers initially to build a solid relationship. Meeting with potential customers to talk through what we’re doing is more powerful than bombarding them with emails and advertising.”

Deposify

Deposify is a fintech start-up offering escrow services for rental deposits. The company provides banking, payments and dispute resolution services for landlords, tenants and letting agents in order to make the renting relationship run more smoothly.

Founded in 2014 by Jon Bayle, a former corporate solicitor, Deposify recently launched its rental deposits product in Dublin and is busy expanding in the US, where it has operations in Boston.

“People put deposits on stuff every day, from real estate to retail – and that’s where the problems start,” says Bayle. “We want to take escrow from legal services and make it an everyday thing for deposits. Deposify lets our users manage and control how and when deposits are paid by delivering an escrow service mobile first – making it available out of traditional banking hours.”

Deposify has partnered with Bank of Ireland for its banking solution and recently closed a €1.1 million funding round, with Delta Partners, Escher Group plc, Enterprise Ireland and private investors participating.

Deposify’s experience as a start-up in the fintech sector has been challenging. “The technology and regulatory hurdles are rightly very high – you’re dealing with people’s money after all. This requires a significant investment in time and money, even before you launch,” says Bayle.

Deposify currently has a team of 13 working across a variety of roles, from technology to sales and marketing.

“Start-ups are a team sport – having great talent is key. I’m not from a technology background, and so when Tony Kelly, former chief executive of a global gaming company, came on board, his expertise and experience in dealing with large online communities and technical teams was invaluable for us.”

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60HC-9XJ1-JCSC-J54S-00000-00100-Year-Old Antitrust Laws Are No Match for Big Tech2020-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexisNEWS100-Year-Old Antitrust Laws Are No Match for Big TechTara Lachapelle

(Bloomberg Opinion) -- When U.S. antitrust laws were first written more than a hundred years ago, the word “data” had a slightly different meaning, referring mainly to facts and manually-compiled information. You didn’t hear it much in everyday language, a... (Bloomberg Opinion) -- When U.S. antitrust laws were first written more than a hundred years ago, the...

(Bloomberg Opinion) -- When U.S. antitrust laws were first written more than a hundred years ago, the word “data” had a slightly different meaning, referring mainly to facts and manually-compiled information. You didn’t hear it much in everyday language, a...

(Bloomberg Opinion) -- When U.S. antitrust laws were first written more than a hundred years ago, the word “data” had a slightly different meaning, referring mainly to facts and manually-compiled information. You didn’t hear it much in everyday language, and it certainly wasn’t associated with trust-busting. In the digital world of today, it’s come to mean the measurable tidbits and inputs that add up to make every program and app — and thus much of the world’s economy — function. And the fact that it isn’t anywhere to be found in antitrust rules is a big problem. To have data is to have power, and collecting it is the lifeblood of four of the most valuable companies in America: Facebook Inc., Google, Amazon.com Inc. and Apple Inc. Together, they are worth more than $5 trillion by market cap. That’s like adding up the market values of Walmart Inc., Johnson & Johnson, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Procter & Gamble Co., Pfizer Inc., Coca-Cola Co., Exxon Mobil Corp., Nike Inc., McDonald’s Corp. and Walt Disney Co. — and then multiplying that sum by two. Calling it “Big Tech” doesn’t even do it justice. These leaders of social-media, online-search, e-commerce and smartphones are so embedded in consumers’ lives that it’s nearly impossible to avoid interacting with them on a given day and handing over reams of data, all for free, in the process: Checking emails, “liking” a post about Taylor Swift, clicking on an enchiladas recipe, joining a group for novice knitters, searching for bug spray and new eyeglass frames, looking up the UPS store’s hours and directions to it, downloading a fitness app and geo-tagging a selfie at the beach — innocuous activities that are meticulously tracked to build a profile of who you are and predict how you’ll spend your money. That power hasn’t gone unnoticed by regulators, Congress and other critics, many of whom wonder whether the companies’ dominance is a sign that current antitrust laws have come up short in regulating this relatively new industry. The answer is, they have — and that’s not all that surprising considering current laws were written with largely traditional businesses in mind, in which a tangible product or a service is built using suppliers and then sold to an end user. How Big Tech makes money can feel a bit more nebulous to an outsider, as well as who exactly is hurt by some of the industry’s practices. Their customers are advertisers and other large and small businesses. The product is, well, you. Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon’s Jeff Bezos, Apple’s Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai of Alphabet Inc., Google’s parent company, appeared last Wednesday over video chat before a Congressional committee that’s investigating whether the industry has a monopoly problem. The Federal Trade Commission is also examining whether past acquisitions by these companies were anticompetitive. The industry doesn’t see it that way; when the members of Congress pointed to known instances of data misuse or overreach, the CEOs often chalked it up to one-offs or minor mishaps, rather than patterns of harmful business practice aimed at squelching competition. Where critics see an anticompetitive move, Big Tech sees a noble effort to improve service for consumers. It’s time that antitrust laws were updated so that regulators can better chaperone the industry — and its treasure trove of data — for it is both an immense intellectual and economic national asset and an opaque force with the power to capitalize on unknowing consumers and suppress rival businesses. Even with the best of intentions to create beneficial services that keep the world connected and informed, the result of Big Tech having such unchecked power over reams of valuable information has been to leave consumers and third-party partners comparatively powerless. Amassing so much data isn’t inherently anticompetitive — nor does it directly hit people’s wallets — but regulators need to look at how it’s collected and used and take action when competition is harmed in the process. Amazon makes for the simplest example of how it can become problematic: The company has been accused of using the highly detailed information it gathers from sellers on its marketplace to inform what products to make for its own private label, AmazonBasics, and to undercut the competition. That’s a major conflict of interest and an unfair advantage over third-party sellers, but there’s nothing those sellers can really do about it — Amazon is practically the only game in town. (Would any reasonable person consider Etsy Inc. or even EBay Inc. to be substitutes?) Bezos said using seller data to aid Amazon’s own brand would be a company violation, but he didn’t deny that it happens and said he’s looking into the issue. This type of accusation against Amazon is the clearest example of monopoly power. Others aren't so clear-cut. My colleague Tae Kim summarizes more of the complaints about the companies here and explains why issues around Google are particularly thorny. This is precisely where the U.S. antitrust framework gets tripped up by the digital-data industry. Take the U.S. guidelines on mergers, which state: A merger enhances market power if it is likely to encourage one or more firms to raise price, reduce output, diminish innovation, or otherwise harm customers as a result of diminished competitive constraints or incentives. Rising prices are the most obvious way mergers can be harmful. But small acquisitions by Big Tech tend to fall into that all-encompassing “otherwise harm” category described above. Facebook’s 2012 takeover of Instagram was harmful because it left social-media users with few alternatives, forcing them in effect to accept the company’s terms and further widening its lead over newcomer apps. Even if regulators couldn’t have predicted this at the time, it’s indisputable now that Facebook dominates social media and that spinning off Instagram would restore competition. (It would probably be good for shareholders, too, as Tae Kim has argued.) The FTC says that antitrust laws were intentionally written in general terms, allowing them to be broadly applied and interpreted in changing times on a case-by-case basis. But it may be that they are overly broad to the point of being antiquated, or at least not specific enough to effectively govern Big Tech. For example, the idea of “prices” should also include the price social-media users pay — the level of data they must fork over and the loss of control they have over that data. Another steep price that can be paid in the digital era is a privacy breach. Facebook’s controversies involving its data aren’t merely public-relations matters — they stem from competitive dominance and insufficient regulatory oversight. Antitrust enforcement also comes down to how regulators define markets. “In the absence of price competition, market definition can be difficult,” Makan Delrahim, the head of the Justice Department’s antitrust division, said in a November speech regarding the data industry. “Antitrust enforcers may need to play an even greater role in zero-price markets,” he said. Rather than a zero-price market, Google and Facebook would argue that they compete healthily in the $333 billion global digital-advertising space, with Amazon nipping at their heels in the U.S. and Apple’s devices serving as conduits. But the ad market provides an incomplete picture, and that framing implies these companies are merely a powerful foursome. Defining the market more narrowly — and more accurately — shows how each one has instead become a monopoly of sorts, having carved out its own silo with few, if any, true competitors. Advertisers may regularly adjust how much money to allocate to each site, but they generally need to be present on all of them. Facebook provides the ability to target ultra-specific subsets of people. Google isn’t just a search engine, it’s the primary verb people use for search, and it further feeds that dominance by scraping useful information from other pages, making its products priority destinations. For sellers of goods, Amazon’s marketplace offers the best reach. App developers don’t have much choice than to agree to the Apple app store’s onerous terms and fees. Consumers don’t pick and choose between these products and services either — they must use them all or accept life under a rock. Regulators would also be more effective if antitrust laws specified how data can be used and with what limitations, as well as requirements for safeguarding it. That would prevent Amazon from having such porous walls between its marketplace and internal brand. It could put an end to Google’s practice of paying to keep its search engine dominant and being able to direct so much traffic toward its own sites. Data should no longer be thought of as just an input for effective advertising, but rather the focal point of the question of whether Big Tech has too much power. If the answer is yes, and the remedy is creating an environment that would allow more Instagrams and Googles to flourish, wouldn’t everyone benefit? This column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of the editorial board or Bloomberg LP and its owners. Tara Lachapelle is a Bloomberg Opinion columnist covering the business of entertainment and telecommunications, as well as broader deals. She previously wrote an M&A column for Bloomberg News. ©2020 Bloomberg L.P.
