urn:contentItem:5R9P-3SK1-F0JP-W31R-00000-00101 WEALTH IDEAS2017-12-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 23101 WEALTH IDEASTIM BLUE

Fair winds are blowing for investors in 2018. Commodity prices, from iron ore to wool, are rising, interest rates are steady and Donald Trump looks to have a tax deal to tweet about. Our sharemarket is resting after cracking the 6000 level, yet it could do better. To find your vehicles of choice, we offer the thoughts of The Weekend Australian 's contributors for the year ahead.

BATTERY BOYOS Lithium, cobalt, nickel, graphite 1. Orocobre (ORE) Orocobre is building an Argentine-based industrial chemicals company through its portfolio of lithium, potash and boron assets. In partnership with Toyota Tsusho Corp (TTC) and JEMSE, it is operating a brine-based lithium operation to produce lithium carbonate for sale to industrial, technical and battery markets. It plans to double lithium carbonate capacity at Olaroz to 35,000 tonnes a year and to build a 10,000-tonne lithium hydroxide plant in Japan. Liked by Patersons. Rated a buy by Citi.

2. Altura Mining (AJM) A small explorer cum developer, it has run up strongly on its big hard-rock lithium project at Pilgangoora in WA, 120km south of Port Hedland, in addition to its diversified iron ore and coal assets in Australia and Indonesia. Already mining ahead of commissioning a production plant, Altura shares have doubled in a year. As Richard Hemming of Under the Radar Report queries, "Who knows how far it can go?"

3. Kidman Resources (KDR) Recent announcements about its half-owned Earl Grey lithium prospect near Southern Cross in WA suggest high-grade intercepts for a mineral upgrade. The company says there is funding flexibility on the back of resource upgrades. Another very positive announcement and it should continue to attract buyers. Liked by Marcus Today, Patersons and StockAnalysis.

4. Syrah Resources (SYR) Near completion of a big graphite mine at Balama in Mozambique. Institutional investors have loaded up on new shares in a recent $74 million capital raising. Some will go to the existing graphite mine and some to develop a battery anode plant at Louisiana in in the US.

5. Ardea Resources (ARL) A nickel cobalt play that has enjoyed a big run - up and down - on its cobalt potential, based on drilling at the Kalgoorlie Nickel Project Cobalt Zone in WA. It also holds an interest in the Lewis Ponds zinc-gold deposit in NSW, and the Mount Zephyr gold and nickel sulphide project in WA. It may have more to go, according to Patersons.

6. Redflow (RFX) Battery maker Redflow has developed a small-scale zinc-bromide flow battery that stores 10KW hours of power. After a false start with a manufacturing facility in Mexico, the company is gearing up to build its batteries in Thailand from early next year. Redflow will need more capital in 2018 to support expansion plans, but its ability to meet underlying demand for its domestic and industrial power storage product is the project's limiting factor. Liked by StockAnalysis.

7. Pilbara Minerals (PLS) Australia dominates world supply of lithium compounds for use in lithium-ion batteries, as well as traditional ceramics and other applications. Expansion of the company's new lithium mine, 120km from Port Hedland, could make it the biggest in the world, to pip the Chinese-owned mine at Greenbushes in the southwest of WA . Liked by StockAnalysis, Under the Radar Report, and is UBS's favourite in the lithium arena.

GOLD 8. Artemis Resources (ARV) A Pilbara explorer gripped by gold fever, Artemis has soared then stalled on disappointing drilling results. It has a joint venture with Toronto-listed Novo Resources at Purdy's Reward 100km south of Karratha, which has some big-name backers. Fellow-seekers of the Witwatersrand-style conglomerate gold, with nuggets like watermelon seeds, include Venturex (VXR), De Grey Mining (DEG), DGO Gold (DGO), Segue (SEG), Marinda Metals (MZN) and Kalamazoo (KZR). After some spectacular four and five-fold leaps in price, most are back in the trenches after drilling disappointments. A punter's paradise.

9. Breaker Resources (BRB) Has a greenfields discovery at Lake Roe, 100km east of Kalgoorlie in WA. Its price has doubled in the past six months, ahead of drilling results expected in March. One to watch if the drilling results prove up, according to Patersons.

10. Gold Road Resources (GOR) Aims to commission its 50 per cent-owned Gruyere goldmine east of Laverton in WA early in 2019, targeting output of about 270,000 ounces a year. The long-life operation will support the company's active exploration program, where recent success indicates that the company is well advanced towards establishing a multi-mine province on its Yamarna Greenstone Belt. Liked by StockAnalysis.

11. Capricorn Metals (CMM) The company has established a viable gold reserve at Karlawinda, southeast of Newman in WA's Pilbara. A feasibility study supports development. The company has raised more funds for an exploration program aimed at expanding mine life beyond nine years. This project is shaping up to be the next significant gold- mine in WA after Gold Road's Gruyere. Liked by StockAnalysis

12. Regis Resources (RRL) A mid-cap goldminer from WA with a strong production and dividend history. Regis's Duketon project has compelling economics - even at current gold prices - and the company is well positioned to generate positive operating cash flow. Management suggests gold production in FY18 of 335,000-365,000 ounces, with all-in costs of $940-$1010 an ounce. While much hangs on future gold prices, its focus on growth plus dividends is liked by Lincoln Indicators and Wise-owl.

BASE METALS 13. Metals X (MLX) Runs a high-margin tin mining operation in Tasmania while expanding reserves and lowering costs at the Nifty copper and gold mine in northern WA. The company has about $100m of net cash and plans a $288m spend in 2018 to build a plant that will treat tin tailings. StockAnalysis says Metals X has exploration potential around the Nifty mine and exposure to nickel and cobalt at the remoteWingellina project.

14. OZ Minerals (OZL) Arguably Australia's pre-eminent copper miner, it is expanding with the underground Carrapateena project, 160km north of Port Augusta. It holds promise for a long life of low-cost copper production. Liked by StockAnalysis.

COAL Tough love 15. Universal Coal (UNV) A rare gem in the unpopular coal sector, Universal is humming along nicely with its two part-owned mines in South Africa: Kangala and the New Clydesdale Colliery. Universal shares spurted after the company announced an inaugural dividend of 1c a share, with expectations the board could stretch to a 2c payout if current trends continue. But they have since retraced some of their gains. Liked by New Criterion.

OIL AND GAS Sagging in surplus 16. Woodside Petroleum (WPL) Woodside is widely thought to be ex-growth and it has struggled to replace reserves and replenish resources in recent years. Yet Woodside has made intelligent moves to shore up future output and its LNG plants can generate more revenue without more reserves being on the books. The preoccupation with reserves has obscured Woodside's high-quality infrastructure and value is now on offer. Liked by InvestSMART.

17. AWE (AWE) Subject to takeover bids for its potential to benefit from higher east coast gas prices, among other reasons. Contracts for the supply of gas from the Otway and Bass Basin projects roll out into 2019, when prices of more than $6 per gigajoule might be expected. AWE's 50 per cent-owned, massive Waitsia gas project north of Perth will be a producer for decades to come for AWE and partner Beach Energy. The price has ticked up but is still cheap, in the eyes of StockAnalysis, saying suitor Minerals Resources could sell non-Perth Basin assets and retain Waitsia for free!

18. Sacgasco (SGC) A Perth-based energy company in a consortium drilling and testing for natural gas in California's northern Sacramento Basin that has already found gas at the Dempsey prospect. Additional targets are being prepared for drilling and testing in 2018. The prize could be large in a market that is likely to find itself short of gas in a couple of years as large LNG export projects are commissioned in the US. Liked by StockAnalysis.

19. 3D Oil (TDO) Holds 100 per cent of the T-49-P permit in the southern Otway Basin, where seismic data indicates prospects with potential for several trillion cubic feet of prospective sales gas. The company is looking for farm-in partners to fund more seismic data and drilling, which is likely in late 2018 or early 2019. Liked by StockAnalysis.

20. FAR (FAR) A 15 per cent partner in the $10 billion SNE oilfield off Senegal, where Woodside has bought a 35 per cent interest. BP is reportedly interested, too. FAR also has an 80 per cent interest in adjacent permits to the south, off the coast of Gambia, where a target for 825 million barrels of oil has been identified. FAR plans to drill this Samo prospect in 2018 after farming out to a fund. Liked by StockAnalysis.

TECH TIDDLERS Share the gear 21. Collaborate Corp (CL8) Runs the online platforms for car and caravan sharing DriveMyCar, MyCaravan and Mobilise, the latter set up for building equipment and perhaps later the office furniture and space market. Since listing in January 2015, it has traded between 1c and 4c. Wise-owl suggests the DriveMyCar unit is tracking towards a cash-flow break-even and values it at 6c.

22. Cape Range (CAG) Focused on accounting and business intelligence services, the formerly Malaysian-based Biztrak business is profitable and cash-flow positive, while user numbers on the platform have grown steadily since inception. Cape Range listed in December 2017 and its tightly held share register and undemanding valuation are attractive qualities, in the eyes of Wise-owl.

23. CCP Technologies (CT1) The "Internet of Things" tech minnow plays in the asset monitoring sector using wireless sensor technology. It has zeroed in on the unmet demand for reliable real-time monitoring of commercial refrigeration facilities. At the moment, a cafe owner may not know that their fridges and freezers have been subject to an overnight power outage and this poses a public health hazard. At the end of the September quarter, CCP had 1000 monitoring points in service, including contracts with Las Vegas casinos and restaurants. Management cites a pipeline of 50,000 sensors, based on existing client orders. With a $6m market cap, CCP is a speccie techie punt liked by New Criterion.

TECH TYROS Electronic athletes 24. Xero (XRO) An online accounting software that gives small businesses and their accountants everything they need to run their operations, from keeping track of all the numbers to preparing reports. Has moved its share base to the ASX from New Zealand. Rated a buy by Citi.

25. IDP Education (IEL) A provider of international student placement services and English language testing services. Lincoln Indicators suggests it would suit an investor looking for a quality education-based business in a sector which, though large, has its corporate challenges. It also owns and operates English language schools in Southeast Asia and organises educational events and conferences globally. It listed on the ASX in 2015 and is 50 per cent-owned by 38 Australian universities.

26. Amaysim (AYS) A reseller on the Optus network and Australia's fourth-largest mobile carrier, amaysim has more than 1 million subscribers and with high fixed costs and high incremental margins, the economics get better as it grows. EBITDA margins have doubled over the past few years and use of a common platform to sell electricity and broadband should generate higher profits. As a reseller, amaysim benefits from Optus's capex without incurring the cost and the model is highly cash generative. The price-earnings ratio makes it look dear but the cash flow shows amaysim is still cheap. Liked by InvestSMART.

27. WiseTech Global (WTC) WiseTech's software is used by 19 of the 20 largest global logistics service providers in more than 125 countries. It's been on a buying spree recently that has added to its client base and in December was added to the S&P/ASX 200 index. Lincoln Indicators suggest it's a long-term growth story, especially with founder Richard White still at the helm.

28. TPG Telecom (TPM) Everyone knows the NBN will lower broadband margins and that consensus has savaged the share price. InvestSMART agrees broadband margins will fall but says there are lots of levers TPG can pull to offset those falls. "As the industry's lowest cost producer we expect volume gains and the corporate business continues to grow both customers and margins. We also think the entry into mobile can be done cheaper and more effectively than what many expect because of TPG's existing infrastructure and the lack of legacy assets to maintain." TPG could seriously disrupt the mobile market - high margin incumbents beware, according to InvestSMART.

29. Appen (APX) Appen is a language technology data and services provider (for speech recognition and content relevance in search engines) to government and corporate enterprises. It earns 95 per cent of its revenue from the US, after buying US rival Leapforce. In short, it helps machines learn to read, write, listen and speak in 150 different languages. Appen employs more than 300 people in six countries. The company has grown earnings well since listing in 2015. Liked by Lincoln Indicators.

30. Next DC (NXT) One of UBS's perennial favourites looks likely to have another strong year in 2018. The launch of Amazon in Australia and the latest range of smartphones only serve to underwrite the ongoing growth of data storage. Next DC will also open three new data centres in each of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane in 2018.

31. MNF Group (MNF) An online voice communications business that is growing organically and through acquisitions. It has a deal to supply voice services to the Victorian government, and in 2017 reached agreement to buy voice conferencing and collaboration business Conference Call International. Other names include Symbio, CallStream, GoTalk and Connexus. The share price has risen four-fold in three years, and keeps moving. Liked by Lincoln Indicators and Under The Radar Report.

32. Trade Me Group (TME) Trade Me is an online marketplace and classified ad platform begun in New Zealand - it's a virtual combination of carsales.com, realestate.com.au, Seek and eBay. With 4.2 million active accounts, Trade Me is as well known in NZ. Despite high market penetration, premium ad evenue grew at least 25 per cent in the company's three online classifieds divisions in 2017. The share price is down because of Facebook's new Marketplace venture and Amazon's launch in Australia, so Trade Me looks excellent value to InvestSMART.

BIOTECHS Bugs a go-go 33. Anatara Lifesciences (ANR) Anatara is developing a natural remedy for scour - diarrhoea in piglets - now treated with antibiotics that are being banned throughout the food chain. Anatara's product Detach is being evaluated by the local veterinary drug gatekeepers. But a big advantage is that the drug was sold in the 1980s under a previous owner. In August, global animal health giant Zoetis said it would exercise an option to develop Detach. Commercial terms are yet to be negotiated, but New Criterion thinks this is likely to lead to fat milestone and royalty cheques for Anatara.

34. Phosphagenics (POH) The biotech play lost its way after its CEO was jailed in 2014 for her part in a $6m fraud against the company. But New Criterion says there are two key reasons to buy now. First, its targeted penetrating matrix (TPM) technology has gained the support of a Japanese partner to develop a transdermal oxymorphone patch. TPM is all about more effective drug delivery through the skin. Second, Phosphagenics could have a potentially lucrative payday in court. The Singapore International Arbitration Centre has just finished hearing a damages action bought by the company against pharma giant Mylan, in relation to a previous licensing deal over the world's most widely used injectable antibiotic. Phosphagenics has claimed $380m. An ambit claim, perhaps, but even an award of a fraction of this amount would dwarf the company's market cap of about $23m.

POTS OF POTENTIAL Intriguing plays, specialty finance and moving in on the banks 35. Money3 (MNY) With plans to move beyond unsecured payday lending, Money3 sees its future as a financier of used motor vehicles for those with a tarnished credit record, and in other secured areas no longer sought by the big financiers. Its shares have eased back from highs of a year ago despite strong net profit through its national network of 66 branches, online Cash Train business and a broker network. Patersons has it as a buy, with a price target of $2.15 in 12 months.

36. Axsesstoday (AXL) A provider of equipment funding for small to medium-sized enterprises in hospitality, transport and other sectors. After a good 2017 financial year, it could move into new sectors and regions, according to Patersons, which rates it a buy with a price target of $2.37.

37. Credit Corp (CCP) The company's core operation lies in debt purchase and debt collection, with 65 per cent share of the Australian market. It recently acquired Cashfirst from Thorn Group. Led by long-serving CEO Thomas Beregi, future growth will look to come from the US, where the offshore expansion has taken time but appears to be bearing fruit. Liked by Lincoln Indicators.

38. Eclipx Group (ECX) A fleet management and leasing operator that also deals in equipment finance and corporate customer loans. The company remains well placed to deliver growth organically and through acquisitions over coming periods. The acquisition of Grays Online, announced in May 2017, should help earnings this year. Liked by Lincoln Indicators.

39. Platinum Asset Management (PTM) In the past year, the company has been a little underweight in the US, and remains so compared to others. Wise-owl regards it as well-diversified and attractive when valuations across the US are sitting on multi-decade highs.

INFRASTRUCTURE Building, building 40. CIMIC (CIM) With all the talk about more infrastructure, the big builders could do well, at home and abroad. A joint venture in which CIMIC subsidiary Leighton Asia holds a 70 per cent stake has secured a $390m contract for construction work at Hong Kong international airport. It's also just won a $2.5bn contract to build Melbourne's West Gate Tunnel. Liked by Patersons. Not cheap, says Padley Today, but one to watch if the market moves lower.

41. Lendlease (LLC) Has suffered a little in the past year, and could rebound. With an Italian partner it recently won a competition to redesign the 100-hectare site of Milan's 2015 World Expo into an innovation and knowledge hub. Liked by Patersons.

SOFT COMMODITIES Tasty tucker 42. Abundant Produce (ABT) A plant science company with two strings to its bow: developing better vegetable seeds for food, such as cucumber, tomato and eggplant, and selling to multinational seed distributors. It is making inroads on the international market for natural cosmetics and nutraceuticals. The company has established sales channels into China and recently announced its Tomato Infusion Daily Face Cream has been added to Alibaba's T-Mall Global "Must Buy" product list.

43. Beston Global Food (BFC) A diversified food stock in South Australia that sells Edwards Crossing and Mable-branded dairy products locally through IGA and Foodland outlets, and exports milk powder, cheese and bottled water to China, Vietnam and Singapore. Under the chairmanship of Roger Sexton, it did a great deal to buy a cheese plant at Murray Bridge. Selling into Asia under the name Kyubu. Liked by Patersons.

44. A2Milk (A2M) The star in the milk market, based on its protein-strong milk that goes well in China and the US. A new chief executive is now at the wheel. Has a high PE of around 50, which might make further price growth hard to achieve. Liked by Bell Potter and Morningstar.

45. Bega Cheese (BGA) An attractive future yet looking a little expensive. Bought Mondelez in Australia, and is completing the integration including rebranding to Bega Vegemite and Bega Peanut Butter. It appears set to be a conglomerate with a wider business than just cheese and milk. Liked by Patersons.

46. Rural Funds Group (RFF) Pays a still-attractive yield despite a share price doubling in two years. Its property portfolio encapsulates almonds, cattle, poultry, vineyards, macadamia and cotton assets. Chief executive David Bryant has a long career in agricultural sciences and investments and continues to lead the business today. Liked by Lincoln Indicators, Under the Radar Report and Padley Today.

MEDICAL MUSINGS Growth with ageing 47. Medical Developments International (MVP) An Australia-based healthcare company, with three segments to its business: pharmaceuticals (selling Penthrox), medical devices (particularly the Space Chamber and Breathy-Alert Peak-Flow meter) and veterinary products. The company operates in Australia, New Zealand and overseas. Liked by InvestSMART. Had a big run from $5 a share to close to $7.

48. Virtus Health (VRT) The market leader in IVF has excellent returns on capital, throws off plenty of cash and its international operations are ticking along nicely. What's more, increasing rates of infertility due to women having children later in life all but guarantees that demand for IVF will grow over the long term. With a price-earnings ratio of 12 and dividend yield of 5 per cent, Virtus in the eyes of InvestSMART offers plenty of value.

HEALTHCARE Regulated growth 49. Lifehealthcare Group (LHC) Imports, develops and distributes high-end surgical and other medical devices. The stock appears under-priced, perhaps in reflection to potential changes in the federal government's prostheses list, yet management has reiterated its full-year guidance of high single to low double-digit growth in revenue.

50. Integral Diagnostics (IDX) Once trading at a discount to its peers, shares in this radiology and imaging company have shot up due to a hostile cash and scrip takeover bid from junior healthcare imaging rival Capitol Health (CAJ). Earlier, a new CEO and CFO had been bringing costs under control, while the balance sheet remained strong.

51. SomnoMed (SOM) Somnomed offers an oral appliance to help those suffering from mild to moderate obstructive sleep apnea. It's a large market with much unmet demand - a 10th centre in the US opened recently under the Renew Sleep Solutions brand. UBS thinks there's a growth market ahead.

INDUSTRIALS Large and lovable 52. Brambles (BXB) Brambles is trading below Morningstar's $12 fair valuation, as investors appear to overlook the growth potential in its pallets business. In the next four years, Brambles will spend $1.5bn on new pallet offerings (nestable pallets, wheeled units, cardboard layer pallets). Morningstar sees potential expansion into adjacent supply chains, such as home and hardware and pharmaceuticals, market segments that could double CHEP's addressable market.

53. BHP (BHP) Has rebounded strongly on rising iron ore prices, yet could do more and perhaps have an on-market share buyback. Citi has it as a buy and a price target of $31.50.

54. Adelaide Brighton (ABC) One for an exposure to strong infrastructure and residential markets. The company is the largest lime producer and second-largest cement supplier in Australia. A recent agreement with Lendlease to supply construction material to the $985m Northern Connector Project in South Australia should bolster the company's ability to maintain a stable dividend yield. Liked by Lincoln Indicators.

55. Coca-Cola Amatil (CCL) Its share price is about 50 per cent below its peak, for an undemanding valuation given the company's balance sheet strength, recent operational improvements and somewhat defensive business model. A mix of capital management initiatives and a rebalancing of the product portfolio has the potential to drive earnings growth, in Wise-owl's eyes.

56. Brickworks (BKW) Despite the name and a stunning building boom, this is not a business at peaky earnings or frothy valuations. The market has difficulty valuing this conglomerate and often just resorts to comparing multiples with peers. Yet Brickworks is nothing like its peers. The property division and investment holdings are the most valuable bits of the business and, while we expect building products earnings to fall over time, there is still value on offer for the conservative investor. Liked by InvestSMART.

57. Goodman Group (GMG) As the owner and developer of warehousing and warehouse facilities, Goodman stands to benefit from the rise of global demand for industrial property. Operations in 16 countries contribute more than half its earnings. Such a foothold allows it to take experience from one market and apply it to another. Accumulate says Morningstar, as it has the most favourable growth outlook given the importance of large-scale, modern warehouses in distribution chains. Rated a buy by Citi.

58. AGL Energy (AGL) AGL stands to win on rising wholesale electricity prices, regardless of whether it closes the coal-fired Liddell Power Station in the Hunter Valley. A hot, dry summer could spike up wholesale electricity prices on a system stretched to capacity - painful for east coast consumers but good for shareholders who already enjoy tasty dividend yields of 4.6 per cent. Liked by Under the Radar Report.

59. Qube (QUB) Qube is progressing on its massive intermodal terminal at Moorebank in western Sydney, to shift freight on rail from Port Botany to warehouses at Moorebank and beyond. Has a "unique portfolio of high quality and strategic infrastructure assets" that should make it a core holding, according to Patersons. Liked by Morningstar.

MANAGED FUNDS Domestic equities 60. Monash Absolute Investment Fund An absolute return fund with a small-cap bias that has returned 11.4 per cent a year over the past five years. InvestSense says such results follow from giving a manager carte blache to run a portfolio in a way that makes most sense, with the objective of maximising long-term value rather than just trying to beat an index. "We think that could be worth paying fees for."

61. Perpetual Pure Microcap Fund Small-cap managers have turned around in the past year, helped especially by a rally in small-cap resources. Perpetual's fund, working an active, bottom-up, value style, has done 13.1 per cent in the past year and 25 per cent a year over the past four years, to earn a "recommended" from Zenith.

62. UBS Microcap Fund Offers exposure to some of the ASX's smallest, most innovative and fastest growing businesses benefiting from structural changes in the economy, digitisation, the ageing population and energy and environmental trends. For example, it has a holding in the Canberra-based windfarm developer Windlab, a listing last August on the ASX (WND). The fund has returned 17 per cent a year over the past three years.

63. UBS Australian Small Companies This fund invests for growth in emerging Australian companies typically between $250m and $4bn in market cap. Targeted sectors include digital disruption, aged care and retirement, renewables and resources. Has earned a tad over 15 per cent a year over the past five years. Morningstar ranks it four star.

64. BT Invest One for self-directed investors. You choose a ready-made portfolio or build your own from a range of shares, managed funds and term deposits. You can get started from $1000 and will be able to monitor your portfolio alongside your everyday banking with full mobile functionality, so you can trade and manage your investments on the go.

65. Advance Growth Multi-Blend Fund A multi manager, diversified fund. About 85 per cent of assets are placed in equities, listed property and commodities, both domestic and international, with the balance mainly in bonds and cash. One for those comfortable with a high level of risk. The fund delivered a 16.4 per cent gain in the year to October, for a three-year return of 7.9 per cent and a five-year return of 9.7 per cent. The minimum investment is $5000.

66. UBS Halo Australian Share Fund An active and concentrated portfolio, with a leaning to companies with good cash flows, be it in insurance, gaming, energy and technology industries. Key holdings include IAG, Tabcorp, Link Administration and Caltex. The fund has returned more than 10 per cent a year over five years.

67. Lazard Select Australian Equity Fund Active managers have found it challenging to outperform the broader market in the past year, yet the Lazard Select Australian Equity Fund - a concentrated portfolio of large-cap equities compiled on a value theme - can boast close to 10 per cent a year over three years and a tad over 14 per cent a year over five years. Highly recommended by Zenith and Lonsec. Minimum investment $20,000.

FIXED INCOME 68. UBS Diversified Fixed Income Fund A mix of global and Australian fixed-income investments, actively managed to deliver income and capital stability. One to consider for portfolio diversity. The fund has a track record of 20 years-plus with returns since inception of 6.8 per cent. Over the past five years, the return was 4.8 per cent.

69. Legg Mason Western Asset Australian Bond Trust An actively managed bond fund that generates income and capital growth, arising from an investment style best described as "value-driven sector rotation". Zenith views Western Asset Management as a standout manager in domestic fixed interest. Highly recommended by Lonsec and Zenith.

INTERNATIONAL FUNDS 70. Munro Global Growth Fund An absolute return fund in international equities, with a leaning to the big tech stocks that have risen strongly over the past 12 months. It has a strict stop-loss discipline. InvestSense says that if you want to invest in the technologies of tomorrow, such as self-driving cars, robotics and artificial intelligence, but are worried about buying at the top, then Munro can provide that exposure with some degree of downside protection. The minimum first investment is $25,000.

71. Australian REITs Zurich Investments Australian Property Securities Fund After a "year of the unexpected" for active managers of property securities, those with better bottom-up stock selection coupled with more flexible investment mandates have enjoyed solid returns. This one has posted a shade over 14 per cent in the past year and close to 14.5 per cent annually over five years, to earn a highly recommended rating from Zenith and Lonsec.

72. Vanguard Global Quantitative Equity Fund A "quant"-style fund that aims to outperform the MSCI World ex-Australia index by 1 per cent (with net dividends reinvested). Has a risk profile similar to that of the index. Given the hot US market, it has done nearly 26 per cent in 12 months. The minimum investment is $500,000.

PROPERTY 73. AMP Capital Wholesale Australian Property Fund A vehicle for retail investors and SMSFs to invest in commercial property, ranging from Australian office, retail and industrial properties. It aims to provide stable returns made up primarily of income with some long-term capital growth. One-year returns are 8 per cent and three-year returns are just over 10 per cent a year. The minimum investment is $10,000 and the fund is recommended by Zenith and Lonsec.

INCOME AND GROWTH 74. MLC Inflation Plus Actively managed to deliver above-inflation returns, where clients can dial in their preferred risk setting. For example, the moderate portfolio aims to deliver a return of 5 per cent a year above inflation (before fees) over five years, regardless of what global markets are doing. Highly recommended by Zenith and Lonsec.

INFRASTRUCTURE 75. AMP Capital Core Infrastructure Fund This fund offers a path to a portfolio of unlisted and listed infrastructure assets, among them Melbourne Airport and Britain's Angel Trains. Since inception, it has delivered more than 21/2 times the return of Australian equities with only 40 per cent of the volatility.

76. Maple-Brown Abbott Global Listed Infrastructure Fund A comprehensive investment process and a stringent definition of infrastructure results in a high conviction portfolio that highlights the core characteristics of listed infrastructure. It has returned 13.6 per cent in the past year and close to 13 per cent a year over three years, to earn Zenith's highly recommended rating.

77. Redpoint Global Infrastructure Fund The fund uses a quantitative approach and typically invests in 100-140 listed infrastructure equities across the globe, which is more than most other funds in this asset class. This approach gives Redpoint a broader universe to search and helps to reduce risk by increasing asset, sector and geographic diversification. The fund has delivered 13.61 per cent a year after fees since inception in April 2012 and is recommended by Lonsec.

EXCHANGE TRADED FUNDS Global diversity 78. Vanguard Australian Property Securities Index ETF (VAP) Owning multiple residential properties doesn't really count as portfolio diversification. The Vanguard Australian Property Security Index ETF might be the answer, as it covers listed Australian real estate investment trusts (A-REITS), with holdings in retail, office, industrial, tourism and multi-sector ventures. It's up 12.8 per cent a year over the past three years. Highly recommended by Lonsec.

79. Montgomery Global Equities ETF (MOGL) A new ETF version of Montgomery's existing global equities managed fund. Apart from investing on a global palette, it aims to provide a minimum annual yield of 4.5 per cent a year with distributions paid twice a year. Like all ETFs, it stands on a sector's performance.

80. iShares Edge Smart Beta ETF (WDMF) Smart beta is a hot sector - this one is up more than 25 per cent in 12 months, which would impress active fund managers. The ETF targets four drivers of global returns: financially healthy firms, inexpensive stocks, smaller companies and trending stocks.

81. UBS IQ MSCI World Ex Australia Ethical ETF (UBW) Offers exposure to as many as 1570 securities on 22 world equities markets, excluding Australia. Besides holdings in the big tech stocks - Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Microsoft - it excludes tobacco companies and producers of "controversial weapons". A good 20 per cent gain in the past year has lifted returns to more than 9 per cent a year since inception in February 2015.

82. iShares Global 100 ETF (IOO) A tracker of the S&P Global 100 index, which covers the world's 100 biggest companies. With a boom on Wall Street and elsewhere, this BlackRock-run ETF ran up more than 23 per cent, to lift the three-year return to more than 12.4 per cent a year.

83. iShares Global Healthcare ETF (IXJ) The fund seeks to track an index, the S&P Global 1200 Healthcare Sector index, which includes large, mid and small-cap companies in biotechnology, healthcare, medical equipment and pharmaceuticals. In a strong year, the ETF gained close to 20 per cent, to make the three-year return of 9.45 per cent a year.

84. Vanguard High Yield Index ETF (VHY) With interest rates low, the search for yield is uppermost in many investors' minds. This Vanguard ETF offers access to high-yield shares, without sacrificing diversification, offering exposure to 50ASX-listed securities expected to deliver higher after-tax yields than the market average. It has an annual management fee of 0.25 per cent a year, and has delivered a return of more than 6 per cent over the past three years.

85. iShares Global Asia 50 ETF (IAA) Top performer by Morningstar records was iShares Asian fund, which gained close to 34 per cent in the year, to lift the three-year return to 17.5 per cent a year. The fund seeks to track the investment results of an index, the S&P Asia 50, based on the performance of the 50 largest companies listed in China, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan.

86. BetaShares WisdomTree Japan ETF After three lost decades, it might be time to tilt to Japan in international investments, as incomes rise and corporate governance changes lead to better dividend payouts. InvestSense suggests the choice is between the currency-hedged Betashares WisdomTree (HJPN) - up almost 24 per cent in a year - or the unhedged iShares MSCI Japan ETF (IJP), up more than 20 per cent.

DIY INCOME 87. Investment-grade corporate bonds Investment-grade corporate bonds are low-risk, defensive investments, which return up to 5 per cent a year. A major benefit of corporate bonds is that the face value of the bond is returned to investors at maturity. Perfect if you think the global market is due for a correction, says Elizabeth Moran of FIIG Securities.

88. Residential mortgage-backed securities Why buy a single, lumpy investment property that will need maintenance and a tenant delivering unknown returns when you can invest in residential mortgage-backed securities? These bonds pay a floating rate of return and regularly pay back principal and interest, reducing risk as the securities age. FIIG Securities suggest you target the tranches typically rated in the "A" range with expected yields of 4.5-5 per cent a year.

89. JCPenney USD high yield bond For investors willing to take on a bit more risk and looking for income, the US high yield market is worth investigating. One liked by FIIG Securities is US retailer JCPenney (NYSE: JCP). It has a senior secured fixed-rate bond maturing in 2023 with a yield to maturity of 6.32 per cent a year. The bond is rated by S&P as BB-, indicating it is seen as higher risk. US retailers have been under pressure, and the bond sold off recently and is now trading below $US100 face value, which FIIG thinks presents value.

SUPERANNUATION 90. Sunsuper Balanced Hard to go past Sunsuper, which in the past year has picked up four titles as the best, from three ratings agencies - Chant West, Super Review and SuperRatings - and Money Magazine. Sunsuper's balanced fund has delivered close to 11 per cent a year for the past five years.

91. Bendigo SmartStart Super The cheapest in the market, anyone can join and it has returned more than 9.3 per cent a year over the past five years. Has a MySuper option with default life cover and the ability to tailor cover to suit individuals. Looks appealing for young people starting out, business owners and those nearing retirement. Online applications. Rated five star by Canstar over the past four years.

INVESTING TOOLS Online share trading 92. Margin Loans Leveraged Direct Investment Loan A lower interest rate margin loan for investors who prefer to manage their own facility. Has an online application form, online tools and integration with the low-fee online broker of choice. Rated five stars by Canstar.

93. CMC Classic Account Competitively priced, with low brokerage fees of just $11 or 0.10 per cent on your first 10 trades within a month. They also offer access to a large number of charting options, market research and education materials to support investors at every level. Liked by Canstar.

SENIOR SPECIALS Cash the house, grab the cards and hit the boats 94. Reverse mortgages â€ƒCanstar suggests you look at Heartland Seniors Finance. Under its Equity Protection Option, you may choose to protect a percentage of the eventual net sale proceeds of your home (10 per cent, 20 per cent or 50 per cent). When your loan is repaid, you or your estate is guaranteed to receive any chosen Equity Protection percentage.

95. Travel credit cards â€ƒBankwest's Zero Platinum card has no annual fee, no currency conversion fees, and complementary travel insurance. ANZ's Rewards Travel Adventures card has a $225 annual fee, then tosses in a return domestic Virgin flight each year, two single-entry Virgin Australia lounge passes a year, no overseas transaction fees on purchases and up to 1.5 rewards points per $1 spent.

96. Term deposits â€ƒME is paying 2.75 per cent a year on 12-month term deposits (interest paid at maturity) for amounts up to $1,000,000. Interest can also be paid monthly at a slightly lower rate. Terms of up to five years are available.

97. Insurance cover while you are away â€ƒCanstar suggests World2Cover's Top Cover, "which offers comprehensive levels of cover at a competitive price". Top Cover customers also have access to unlimited medical cover (without any excess) and children under the age of 25 are fully covered when travelling with a guardian.

98. Car insurance â€ƒ Budget Direct's Gold Comprehensive cover stands out in Canstar's eyes as good value, with a well-rounded suite of features, plus a 15 per cent premium discount for online policy applications, multi-policy discounts and optional roadside assistance.

99. Insurance while you're still working â€ƒCanstar suggests NobleOak's Direct Life and Direct Income Protection cover for competitive prices and similar to insurance typically only accessible via an adviser. For direct income protection, consumers can cover an annual income of up to $400,000 (which could be taken as a $25,000 monthly benefit), and instead of a typical two-year benefit period one can opt to have this paid until 65 while they are unable to work due to illness or injury.

100. International trading â€ƒWant to go global share trading? Interactive Brokers Australia allows access to 100 exchanges worldwide, with brokerage as low as $US 1 a trade in the US market, as well as offering features such as in-depth reporting and charting options. (Note, the minimum opening balance is $US10,000 and there is a monthly activity fee of up to $US20.)

101. Online retailing Kogan.com (KGN) The online retailer is up threefold in six months, a beneficiary of lower prices in telecoms and tie-ins to insurance and soon budget healthcare through Medibank. Media reports suggest the principals have sold down their stakes slightly to a large overseas organisation. Can it keep going, asks Under the Radar Report? "We're not sure, but you won't be bored," is the reply.The Weekend Australian accepts no responsibility for these product offerings. The author owns BHP and Brambles shares. Some of the firms featured have or seek corporate work with several of the stocks mentioned. Readers should contact a licensed financial adviser.

value.Title: 202. Uber hearings, Davos, CLOUD Act, and John Perry Barlow

Extracts.SummaryText: ... the Justice Department and Big Tech are hoping to head the Court off with a legislative solution[6]. Jamil Jaffer[7] explains what the CLOUD Act will do. I point out who's missing from the Grand Coalition and question whether Big Privacy has the clout to stop the act. Fancy Bear hackers seeking high-tech weapons data from US defense contractors[8] get lucky - up to 40% of their phishing links strike paydirt. Michael Mutek explains what this likely means for the Defense Department - more regulation ...

urn:contentItem:5RN2-KPC1-F03R-N49B-00000-00202. Uber hearings, Davos, CLOUD Act, and John Perry Barlow2018-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexis202. Uber hearings, Davos, CLOUD Act, and John Perry BarlowStewart Baker

Feb 14, 2018( The Volokh Conspiracy: http://reason.com/volokh Delivered by Newstex) ;; Cyberlaw Podcast alumnus Marten Mickos[1] was called before the Senate Commerce Committee to testify about HackerOne's bug bounty program. But the unhappy star of the hearings was Uber[2], which was heavily criticized for having paid out a large bonus under cloudy circumstances. Sen.

Blumenthal and others on the Hill[3] treated the payment as more ransom than bounty and pilloried Uber for not disclosing what they called a breach. Even Uber, under new management, was critical of its performance[4]. As the only cyberlaw podcast with a Davos correspondent, we ask Alan Cohn to give highlights of the event from a cybersecurity point of view. I bring the color commentary and snark. With Microsoft Ireland case[5] heading to argument, the Justice Department and Big Tech are hoping to head the Court off with a legislative solution[6]. Jamil Jaffer[7] explains what the CLOUD Act will do. I point out who's missing from the Grand Coalition and question whether Big Privacy has the clout to stop the act. Fancy Bear hackers seeking high-tech weapons data from US defense contractors[8] get lucky - up to 40% of their phishing links strike paydirt. Michael Mutek explains what this likely means for the Defense Department - more regulation, probably. Whether more regs and more compliance will produce more security is the question no one can answer. A cyberdiplomacy office[9] is back from the dead, sort of: Secretary Tillerson now says he'll create a bureau for cyberspace headed by an Assistant Secretary. And, as Jamil explains, the fight switches to which undersecretary will oversee the office. Nick Weaver[10] and Jamil comment on the news that Justice has pulled in an impressive haul of cyber-fraudsters[11], bookended by doubts whether any hackers[12] can ever be extradited from places like the UK and Ireland. Because, face it, how many can't claim to be on the spectrum? I close with a tribute to John Perry Barlow[13], who died last week. If you wanted to know how many women would fall for a combination Grateful Dead lyricist, technologist, and cowboy, John could tell you. Exactly. As always The Cyberlaw Podcast is open to feedback. Send your questions, suggestions for interview candidates or topics to CyberlawPodcast@steptoe.com[14] or leave a message at +1 202 862 5785.; Download the 202nd Episode (mp3)[15]. Subscribe to The Cyberlaw Podcast here[16]. We are also on iTunes[17], Pocket Casts[18], and Google Play[19] (available for Android and Google Chrome)! [ 1]: https://www.steptoe.com/resources-detail-12228.html [ 2]:   https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-cyber-congress/uber-says-hackers-behind-2016-data-breach-were-in-canada-florida-idUSKBN1FQ2YO [ 3]:   https://schakowsky.house.gov/uploads/20180205%20Schakowsky-Lujan%20letter%20to%20Senate%20Commerce%20re%20Uber%20and%20FTC.pdf [ 4]:   http://thehill.com/policy/technology/372596-uber-no-justification-for-covering-up-data-breach [ 5]:   https://www.lawfareblog.com/cloud-act-welcome-legislative-fix-cross-border-data-problems [ 6]:   https://www.hatch.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/releases?ID=EDDBD9E1-D345-48DC-A125-FC97B49FE243 [ 7]:   https://www.law.gmu.edu/faculty/directory/adjunct/jaffer_jamil_n [ 8]:   https://federalnewsradio.com/cybersecurity/2018/02/russian-hackers-exploit-weakness-in-us-cyber-defense-2/ [ 9]:   http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/372573-tillerson-proposes-creating-bureau-to-focus-on-cyber-issues-digital [ 10]:   http://www1.icsi.berkeley.edu/~nweaver/ [ 11]:   http://www.zdnet.com/article/justice-department-indictment-february-cybercrime-ring/ [ 12]:   https://www.theguardian.com/law/2018/feb/05/hacking-suspect-lauri-love-wins-appeal-against-extradition-to-us [ 13]:   https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2018/02/john-perry-barlow-internet-pioneer-1947-2018 [ 14]: CyberlawPodcast@steptoe.com [ 15]:   http://www.steptoe.com/staticfiles/TheCyberlawPodcast-202.mp3 [ 16]:   http://www.steptoe.com/feed-Cyberlaw.rss [ 17]:   https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/steptoe-cyberlaw-podcast/id830593115?mt=2 [ 18]:   http://pcasts.in/steptoe [ 19]:   https://play.google.com/music/listen#/sww

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDY-70G1-DXH2-60MF-00000-00249 Migrant Children Being Shifted To HHS Care; President Trump Imposes New Iran Sanctions; FedEx Sues U.S. Over Huawei Restrictions. Aired 5:30-6a ET2019-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexisEARLY START5:30 AM ESTNEWSInternational062504CN.V34249 Migrant Children Being Shifted To HHS Care; President Trump Imposes New Iran Sanctions; FedEx Sues U.S. Over Huawei Restrictions. Aired 5:30-6a ETChristine Romans, Dave Briggs, Frederik Pleitgen, Karoun Demirjian, Sherisse Pham, John Berman, Alisyn Camerota

Nearly 250 migrant children held in reportedly poor conditions at a Customs and Border Protection facility in Texas will be moved today after a team of lawyers, doctors and advocates warned of major health and hygiene problems -- including in some cases a lack of soap -- after visiting multiple U.S. Customs and Border Protection facilities in the state. President Trump signed an executive order yesterday imposing new sanctions on Iran as retaliation for Iran's downing last week of a U.S. military drone, and says the "hard- hitting" sanctions will financially punish Iran's Supreme Leader. U.S. delivery company FedEx has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. government, arguing that it should not be required to enforce federal government export bans.

[05:31:58] CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN ANCHOR: Billions in emergency funding on the line. The liberal wing of the Democratic Party could hold it up, demanding more help for kids along the border.

DAVE BRIGGS, CNN ANCHOR: "She's not my type." That's the president's dismissal of a woman accusing him of rape decades ago. Hear how Jean Carroll responded to that.

ROMANS: New sanctions mean the end of diplomacy. Big pushback from Iran against the U.S. as world leaders prepare to head to the G20.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BILL GATES, FOUNDER, MICROSOFT: Well, technology has become so central that government has to think, OK, what does that mean?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: And, Bill Gates joins the call to regulate big tech. Why he says it's time his own industry was more closely watched.

Welcome back to EARLY START on a Tuesday, everybody. I'm Dave Briggs.

ROMANS: And I'm Christine Romans.

BRIGGS: Morning.

ROMANS: It is exactly 32 minutes past the hour, folks, and we start with the ongoing immigration battle playing out in Congress.

Torture facilities -- that's what an on-site doctor compared the conditions to where migrant children are being held along our southern border. No soap, soiled clothes, poor hygiene. And now, emergency funding to fix those problems at the border could be in jeopardy.

House Democrats emerging from a tense late-night meeting with Speaker Pelosi agreeing to review specific changes to a $4.6 billion proposal. Why? Democrats in the Progressive and Hispanic Caucuses argue it does not go far enough addressing those humanitarian needs.

A Democratic source calls it the hardest Nancy Pelosi has had to work in her speakership.

The speaker addressed the border issue before the meeting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA): Families belong together in America. Everyone has rights. Immigrants have rights. And we just have to beat that drum across the next couple of weeks. And as we do so, we must also pass legislation that meets the humanitarian needs at the border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: And urgently because the clock is ticking on several fronts. A vote on the Democratic proposal remains set for today. Lawmakers leave Washington for a weeklong recess on Thursday, and the president pushed back his time line but still says the deportations will move ahead in just 12 days.

The chair of the House Democratic Caucus recently outlined leadership's border strategy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. HAKEEM JEFFRIES (D-NY): We should provide the humanitarian assistance necessary to change the conditions along the border, particularly as it relates to immigrant children. But we need to make sure that there are guardrails that are erected so that we do not inadvertently fund the reckless Trump deportation machine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Without some version of emergency immigrant funding, Health and Human Services Sec. Alex Azar says that the effect on HHS would be, quote, "like a government shutdown."

ROMANS: All right. So, help coming immediately for nearly 250 migrant children held at a Customs and Border Protection facility in Clint, Texas. Now, the Department of Health and Human Services says the children will be shifted into its shelter system by today.

[05:35:03] Our Jake Tapper asked Vice President Mike Pence about poor health and hygiene conditions on Sunday and Pence pivoted to politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAKE TAPPER, CNN CHIEF WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT, CNN ANCHOR, "THE LEAD WITH JAKE TAPPER": But we have money to give toothpaste, and soap, and blankets to these kids in this facility in El Paso County. Right now we do.

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, of course, we do.

TAPPER: So why aren't we? PENCE: My point -- my point is it's all a part of the appropriations process. Congress needs to provide additional support to deal with the crisis at our southern border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROMANS: As of June 10th, more than 52,000 -- 52,000 unaccompanied children have been transferred from DHS (Department of Homeland Security) to HHS (Health and Human Services). That's a 60 percent increase over last year.

BRIGGS: An extraordinary denial from President Trump in the face of a rape allegation from the mid-1990s. Now, according to the president, writer E. Jean Carroll is totally lying when she claims he sexually assaulted her in a New York City department store.

Mr. Trump tells "The Hill", quote, "I'll say it with great respect. Number one, she's not my type. Number two, it never happened. It never happened, OK?"

Now, watch Carroll's reaction when Anderson Cooper reads her the president's remarks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR, "ANDERSON COOPER 360": He said, "I'll say it with great respect. Number one, she's not my type. Number two, it never happened. It never happened, OK?"

E. JEAN CARROLL, TRUMP ACCUSER: I love that.

COOPER: You love --

CARROLL: I am so glad I am not his type. I am so glad. This is -- this was 20 years ago and I probably was, at that moment, in that five minutes, the most attractive woman in Bergdorfs -- in that one bit of time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Carroll has been an advice columnist for "Elle" magazine for 26 years.

She alleges Mr. Trump attacked her in one of the stores dressing rooms, a description that mirrors accusations of several other women.

The president has denied accusations of sexual misconduct by more than a dozen women.

ROMANS: President Trump doesn't think he needs congressional approval for a military strike against Iran.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I like the idea of keeping Congress abreast, but I wouldn't have to do that. SAAGAR ENJETI, CHIEF WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT, HILL.TV: Sure. Well, Nancy Pelosi actually said you must have congressional approval. So you disagree with her on that?

TRUMP: I disagree.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROMANS: Members of Congress have debated this question of the president's authority, especially in the wake of the attack the president called off last week. He ordered that strike in retaliation for Iran downing an unmanned American spy plane.

Senate Democrats weighing whether to block the annual defense policy bill. The idea would be to force a vote on an amendment requiring congressional approval for any war with Iran.

BRIGGS: Meantime, the president targeted Iran's supreme leader with new sanctions Monday. He warned that U.S. restraint is limited.

Overnight, the Iranian Foreign Ministry slapped back, saying the new sanctions mean the White House is, quote, "closing the channel of diplomacy forever."

CNN's Frederik Pleitgen is standing by live in Iran with the latest. Fred, they seem -- these sanctions largely symbolic on the surface. What's the reaction there?

FREDERIK PLEITGEN, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, I think the Iranians, Dave, are also saying that these sanctions are just symbolic. But at the same time, symbolic obviously means something here as well and they're saying that they believe that this is something that crushes any sort of chances of diplomacy between Iran and the United States.

It was quite interesting because the president, Hassan Rouhani -- he came out in a speech -- in a press conference earlier today and absolutely lashed out at the United States and the White House, specifically, saying that -- he said, and this is a quote -- that "The White House is suffering from mental disability and no sane person would do what the United States is doing."

Essentially, what the Iranians are saying is they are saying that because of the White House, on the one hand, is saying that it wants Iran to go back to the negotiating table. But at the same time, the sanctioning senior figures -- but not just the supreme leader, but also saying they're going to sanction the foreign minister as well. That means that the U.S. is lying about any intention to want to go back to talks with the Iranians.

The Iranians for their part, of course, are saying that it's precisely these sanctions that are preventing them from going back to the negotiating table. They say only if the sanctions are dropped will they return to the negotiating table.

It's also quite interesting. A senior adviser to Hassan Rouhani coming out earlier today and saying the foreign minister being sanctioned by the United States means that he's slowly turning into a Nelson Mandela for Iran, Dave.

BRIGGS: How about that for a comparison? Fred Pleitgen live for us in Tehran this morning. Thank you, sir.

Let's discuss all this with "Washington Post" congressional reporter Karoun Demirjian. She's a CNN political analyst. Good to see you.

ROMANS: Good morning.

KAROUN DEMIRJIAN, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST, CONGRESSIONAL REPORTER, THE WASHINGTON POST: Good morning.

BRIGGS: So, these sanctions -- will they have any impact, and what is the Trump administration's central goal in Iran? Is it repackaging the JCPOA in some sort of USMCA type of manner?

DEMIRJIAN: If it is, it's also stiffening it incredibly because I think that with the -- the administration had the opportunity last year to strengthen and stiffen the JCPOA and they threw that out the window. Now, whether that was a branding issue because it was too closely tied to Obama -- you could make that argument -- given that they're saying we're open to talks.

[05:40:02] I think, though, given the fact that there were frustrations existing around that JCPOA in the first place, whatever they're going to settle on -- and I'm talking about the Trump administration's position here -- is going to have to be a lot more stringent and a lot more punishing on Iran because they've set this standard for themselves of never being able to get a nuclear weapon.

The yield to control the indefinite future, that's a very hard thing to do in a world in which there is nuclear power going around and other states have ambitions, too, that Iran considers regional enemies. And so, it's just -- it's a much more difficult equation for the Trump administration to get everything that they want with that much more -- much more punishing approach because they say the Obama --

BRIGGS: Yes.

DEMIRJIAN: -- administration was too light-handed.

ROMANS: Karoun, we're hearing this morning some pretty incredible details about this meeting that went on for several hours last night among Democrats. And one source telling us that Nancy Pelosi is having the hardest -- doing the hardest work of her speakership right now, trying to sort of wrangle the left wing of her party who are very, very angry about funding at the border.

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said this. "We need to stop funding the detention of children under any and all circumstances. I will not fund another dime to allow ICE to continue its manipulative tactics."

There are a lot of others who have said similar things. You heard Congressman Hakeem Jeffries just a few minutes ago.

Where are the Democrats right now on this and could it end up being something like basically, a government shutdown for border funding?

DEMIRJIAN: If they can't figure this out quickly then yes, because we're looking at just a few days left in the week right now. And if we believe what the secretary of Health and Human Services said, this is dire. And the end of the week is the end of the month and Congress goes on vacation for a week after that, so the clock is ticking.

It seems like everybody in the Democratic Party ultimately wants to do a similar thing, which is improve the situation for the children at the border. Improve the situation at any sort of facility they might find themselves in. But there's this concern that OK, if we keep throwing money at the problem and we don't put any conditions on it to force the government to spend that money in the way that we want them to.

And I think that these latest reports about lack of soap, lack of toothbrushes, lack of basic facilities for these children really, really struck a nerve that has broken the patience of a lot of people to say OK, we'll put the check -- we'll sign the check right now and assume that we can fix the problems later.

They're saying no, you want to do everything at once. Otherwise, we have no guarantee that we're not just kind of endorsing this $4.5 billion. And so, that's the situation you've got right now.

Is it something that you could resolve? Seemingly so if you could put stringent enough conditions on how that money is spent. But this is the debate that they have to resolve today, basically, if they want to be able to get this to happen, especially because it's not the endgame. Whatever happens in the House has to be reconciled with the Senate and that could, itself, be a fairly --

ROMANS: Right.

DEMIRJIAN: -- thorny process because there's --

BRIGGS: Yes.

DEMIRJIAN: -- Republicans that have to be convinced in the Senate and the bipartisan game again.

BRIGGS: And expect this issue to play out on a larger scale Wednesday and Thursday when the Democratic debates begin.

ROMANS: Yes.

BRIGGS: You've got 20 --

DEMIRJIAN: For sure.

BRIGGS: -- Democrats taking the stage.

And the president has attempted to suggest that look, the Democrats don't want to do anything on our southern border.

Will one of those candidates emerge from the pack with a central plan to address our southern border and immigration overall?

DEMIRJIAN: I mean, it's going to be very interesting to see who is able to do that in a comprehensive fashion. And thus far, most of the pitches that have been made are about health care, which affects --

BRIGGS: Yes.

DEMIRJIAN: -- pretty much everybody. Students loans, which affects a lot of people.

The immigration issue at the border -- you have to -- there's a lot of people in the country that might not be watching even though it's a huge story that we're all talking about right now. And to make a case that appeals to just the greater human sensibility on this issue and also gets really serious about financial matters and takes the issue of immigration seriously, I don't think --

You've got diversity views in the Democratic Party. Some people want to have a more open border policy. We've heard proposals like that being made. A lot of the candidates are saying well, no, you can't do that completely. You have to regulate the border in some way.

ROMANS: Right.

DEMIRJIAN: There's proposals about what -- how many visas and for long do you give to undocumented immigrants who are already in the country.

All of these things are going to be competing. There really isn't a firm middle ground in the Democratic Party right now, except for they want to do something that is not just focused on border security -- that is a little bit more generous to the plight of these migrants. What that is though, and how much they can make that appeal to everybody across the board is the challenge, generally speaking, for the Democrats right now.

ROMANS: Sure.

BRIGGS: Indeed.

ROMANS: All right. Karoun Demirjian, nice to see you.

DEMIRJIAN: Nice to see you, too.

ROMANS: Thanks for stopping by.

BRIGGS: Thank you.

ROMANS: All right, 44 minutes past the hour.

Bill Gates calling on the United States government to step up its regulation of big tech. The founder of Microsoft says companies like the one he created have so much influence on culture, on business, on life, that they must be constantly monitored.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GATES: Well, technology has become so central that government has to think OK, what does that mean about elections, what does it mean about bullying, things like privacy. I'm sure they'll -- and there should be, at some point, federal regulation that relates to that.

The fact that now this is the way people consume media has really brought it into a realm that we need to shape it so that the benefits outweigh the negatives.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

[05:45:10] ROMANS: Gates' remarks coming on the same day Senators Mark Warner of Virginia, and Josh Hawley of Missouri introduced a bill that could force companies like Google, Amazon, and Facebook to reveal how much money they make off of your data.

BRIGGS: All right. Ahead, shipping companies connect the world, so what should they do when goods from one world power are banned from another? FedEx is now suing to make that point.

BRIGGS: FedEx sits at the global intersection between commerce and trade and now, the shipping giant is suing the U.S. Commerce Department, pushing back against new restrictions aimed at the embattled Chinese tech firm Huawei.

"CNN BUSINESS" reporter Sherisse Pham joining us live from Hong Kong. Sherisse, hard to find a more consequential corporate battle than this one.

[05:50:06] SHERISSE PHAM, REPORTER, "CNN BUSINESS": This is a massive consequential corporate battle -- you're absolutely right -- and Huawei -- excuse me -- FedEx really caught in the crossfire here.

FedEx -- this lawsuit coming as FedEx is under fire in China for mishandling several packages related to Huawei. They have had to apologize twice in the last month and it hasn't exactly satisfied Beijing and it hasn't exactly satisfied Chinese netizens.

So, CEO Fred Smith saying in an interview to Fox News -- look, we do not have the capacity and the wherewithal to be the policemen of millions of packages. We can't enforce these restrictions that you have on Huawei and other companies.

Have a listen to what he had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FRED SMITH, CEO, FEDEX: The increasing use of restrictions on exports and imports by the Commerce Department and various geopolitical and trade disputes creates just an impossible burden. We are expected to be policemen for these export and import controls. (END VIDEO CLIP)

PHAM: These U.S. restrictions have left so many companies -- American and international companies scrambling to figure out what they can and cannot sell to Huawei. FedEx just the latest one to come out and say we can't handle all of these pressures.

And look, this is really a huge development because the Commerce Department has said all along that these restrictions on Huawei and other companies are a national security concern. You just heard the FedEx CEO there say it's not -- that it's related to geopolitics and trade restrictions.

The Commerce Department has said that they have not reviewed the FedEx lawsuit yet but they look forward to defending Commerce's role in the protection of U.S. national security.

BRIGGS: Yes, and further complicating the G20 this week.

Thank you, Sherisse Pham, live for us in Hong Kong.

ROMANS: All right, let's get a check on "CNN Business" this morning.

Taking a look at global markets, you can see leaning slightly lower. But look, Hong Kong down one percent but each of those other -- Shanghai, Hong Kong showing some weakness, but mostly here. This is what I would call indecision.

On Wall Street, stocks barely moved on Monday and they're barely moving right now. The next big event is the G20 summit where President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will talk trade. No deal expected, but that meeting could set the tone for the next phase of the trade war.

The Dow finished up just eight measly points. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq down.

Look for the month, though. This is the last trading week of the month and the Dow was up almost eight percent this month, the S&P 500 up more than seven percent, and the Nasdaq up nine percent. So, the month -- it has done very well.

The Dow is just 99 points below the record closing high it set in October. And the S&P is also just below its all-time high set last week.

McDonald's sales are on fire. The reason, its decision to switch from frozen beef patties to fresh beef last year. That change means a 30 percent spike in sales of the classic Quarter Pounder over the past year.

McDonald's made the change to appeal to customers who want to know where their food comes from. It's the biggest supply chain change since it started serving all-day breakfast in 2015.

A Quarter Pounder with cheese -- think about that for five minutes. We'll be right back.

[05:57:12] ROMANS: A big mystery in Utah. Police in Salt Lake City say a University of Utah student has been missing more than a week. She was last seen at a park before she vanished.

Twenty-three-year-old MacKenzie Lueck arrived at Salt Lake City International Airport in the early morning hours last Monday after visiting a family in California. She then took a Lyft ride to a park in North Salt Lake, miles from where she lived and has not been seen since.

Lyft and the driver are cooperating with police. The driver confirmed the route she took, telling police MacKenzie met someone after being dropped off.

BRIGGS: Joining the Washington Nationals, the Los Angeles Dodgers now plan to extend the protective netting past the far ends of each dugout at Dodger Stadium. This comes after a fan was hit in the head by a foul ball Sunday. That woman, Kaitlyn Salazar, spoke about the incident.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KAITLYN SALAZAR, HIT BY FOUL BALL: You know in those movies where people -- like, when a bomb goes off and you hear an eerie sound and then, like, the scene starts to get fadey and then everyone sounds like mumbled? Yeah, like that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: There has been greater scrutiny on fan safety after a woman died last year when she was hit by a line drive foul ball at Dodger Stadium. And just last month, a 4-year-old girl was struck in the head by a line drive during a game in Houston.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WORLD CUP ANNOUNCER: Steps up -- Rapinoe shot -- goal. U.S. leads.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ROMANS: The U.S. Women's National Team is in the -- in the quarterfinals now of the 2020 Women's World Cup. They defeated Spain Monday, two to one, behind two Megan Rapinoe penalty kicks.

Team USA, the defending World Cup champs, will now meet France, the host nation, on Friday.

The tickets are like through the roof, right?

BRIGGS: Yes, thousands of dollars. And some feel that is the true final, which would be great. Three o'clock Eastern time, 12:00 Pacific. ROMANS: All right, thanks for joining us. I'm Christine Romans.

BRIGGS: I'm Dave Briggs. "NEW DAY" starts right now. We'll see you tomorrow.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: House Democrats at odds over implementing at strategy at the border.

PENCE: No American should approve of this mass influx of people coming across our border.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It doesn't take more than common sense to know that you need to give kids soap and toothbrushes. The conditions are inhumane.

ROMANS: Twenty-twenty Democratic hopefuls prepare to take the stage for the first round of debates.

JULIAN CASTRO (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The challenge is how do you say things in a way the American people can understand?

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is our chance to dream big, fight hard, and win.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: This is NEW DAY with Alisyn Camerota and John Berman.

JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR: I've been reading about you in the papers all morning.

ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR: Oh, tell me more.

BERMAN: Your interview with E. Jean Carroll yesterday on the show got written up everywhere.

CAMEROTA: Well, thank you for saying that. She said a lot of provocative things and we just watched her. You and I processed what had happened to her 23 years ago, she says, at the hands of Donald Trump. And so, obviously, President Trump had to respond to it.

BERMAN: It's interesting, still, it took three days from the publishing of her book for it to get any traction, but we'll talk much more about that in a little bit.

urn:contentItem:60CY-RJ21-JCSC-J4H2-00000-00250 million people to lose jobs this year – Microsoft President2020-07-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexisNEWS250 million people to lose jobs this year – Microsoft PresidentObinna Ezugwu

Smith Brad Smith, President of Microsoft has said a quarter of a billion people could lose jobs this year as the world faces staggering jobs challenge not helped by the outbreak of Coronavirus pandemic. Smith said millions will need to learn new skills to ... Smith Brad Smith, President of Microsoft has said a quarter...

Smith Brad Smith, President of Microsoft has said a quarter of a billion people could lose jobs this year as the world faces staggering jobs challenge not helped by the outbreak of Coronavirus pandemic. Smith said millions will need to learn new skills to ...

Smith Brad Smith, President of Microsoft has said a quarter of a billion people could lose jobs this year as the world faces staggering jobs challenge not helped by the outbreak of Coronavirus pandemic. Smith said millions will need to learn new skills to get jobs, or even to hang on to their old one, as the digitisation of economies races ahead. Microsoft recently announced massive plan to deliver skills and training to 25 million people globally this year, offering training, skills, certifications and help finding jobs with the help of Microsoft-owned LinkedIn. Smith, however, conceded that many jobs in many countries would be beyond the reach of digital retraining. “It’s true that the nature of work varies widely around the world. Not all jobs can be digitised, particularly in the developing world. “We live in a world of internet inequality – if we don’t do something about it we are going to exacerbate all the other inequalities that we all worry about. This is a task beyond any one company or any one government but if we can reach 25 million people we will feel like we are doing our part.” Microsoft will spend $20m on this programme, which will strike many as fairly small given this is a company whose value has increased by $500bn in the past year. If big US tech looked powerful before Covid-19, it looks imperious now. Just five companies make up 20% of the value of the S&P 500 index. Does he understand why many feel big tech is too powerful and needs reining in? “Tech is a powerful tool but it can also be a formidable weapon in the wrong hands,” he says. “So this is a critical time for technology, it has more responsibility than ever.” “I think people have more questions than ever and that’s not a bad thing. To ensure that technology is a force for good, governments need to move more quickly to develop technology-focused laws. While tech companies need to exert some self-restraint.” Getting global agreement on how to regulate and tax technology has proved notoriously difficult and many countries are nervous as the increasing digitisation of their economies makes it harder to generate the tax revenue they will need to pay for the trillions of dollars of damage Covid-19 has done. Advances in technology will also lead to an increase in automation and AI which may only hasten mass unemployment. What responsibility does Mr Smith feel that tech companies have to pay for the changes to employment that they are ushering in? “I think the good news is that governments have all the tools they need to make sure that tech companies remain responsive and responsible under the rule of law,” he says. “Fundamentally the responsibility of companies and countries is to make sure that people have the skills to ensure they reap the benefits rather than suffer from the consequences of the changes unleashed. “I think we all need to recognise that tech cannot solve everything, but nothing can be solved without us.”

This week, we talk about the big three - Apple, Google and Facebook - and a NYTimes op-ed by Robert Reich called, Big Tech Has Become Way Too Powerful.
