Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XV8-K2J1-DY19-C22G-00000-002019 delivers surprises and surprising returns2019-12-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexis2019 delivers surprises and surprising returnsLucy Battersby

Australia's stock market increased more than 20 per cent in 2019 and hit all-time highs, despite deep uncertainty.

Australia's stock market reached new historical highs during 2019 even though it was missing a key ingredient usually required for financial success - certainty.

Waves of surprises kept coming in the forms of interest rate cuts, a surprise Coalition election victory, aggressive overnight tweets from US President Donald Trump and the resultant Chinese currency retaliation, mass demonstrations and short seller attacks.

Despite all this, the S&P/ASX 200 managed to close 20 per cent higher at 6794 points over the year to December 24. Despite a weakening economy, many household names reached prices well above anyone's expectations. Fortescue, Wesfarmers, CSL, Qantas, and JB Hi-Fi all ended the year in uncharted territory.

The investment director at Bennelong Australian Equity Partners, Julian Beaumont, says the past twelve months held a lot of surprises.

"Fair to say that 2019 was a better year than most would have ever expected. If you were able to predict the uncertainty hanging over markets from the trade-war, Brexit, Hong Kong riots, weaker than expected global and domestic growth, and poor corporate earnings, then you wouldn't probably have predicted a strong market.

"And it really just goes to show that whatever is happening politically, socially, and on a macro front, aren't necessarily the drivers of stock market returns. Ultimately the biggest driver of returns this year was interest rates and their precipitous fall."

The lower interest rate environment boosts other asset prices. So while stock prices might be more expensive than ever before, this is not because companies are performing better than ever before.

"Over-valuation has to be put in context. And right now when you consider where interest rates are, where housing yields are, where property cap rates are, then in that context equity is actually probably rationally priced. From the point of view of earnings and dividend yield they are actually quite attractive versus the [other asset classes].''

IFM's outgoing chief executive Brett Himbury said the current investment climate was the toughest he has seen since the early 1980s due to low interest rates, geopolitical volatility in advanced markets, the rise of "burdensome" regulation, and levels of trust in financial services being at an "all-time low".

"Most governments, except Australia, are really fiscally constrained. They've got an enormous amount of debt so they've got very little strategic flexibility to generate growth,'' he said.

Unusually, advanced markets have more geopolitical risk than emerging markets currently, he says, which makes it very tough for investors.

"You put all these things together and I honestly think it's the toughest environment we've seen since 1982. I don't envy the job of chief investment officers trying to allocate, whether they're going to go to Australia or not, hedge or not hedge, cash and fixed interest or listed equities."

So what were the best, worst, and most interesting performances of 2019?

Winners

Fortescue, up 184 per cent to $10.91

The iron-ore pure play had the biggest gains of the S&P/ASX200 during 2019, rising from $3.80 to $10.91. The company has been surfing a boom in iron ore prices driven by extremely strong demand from Chinese steel mills and global supply constraints after a fatal dam collapse at an iron ore mine in Brazil. Iron ore prices hit $US120 per tonne early in 2019, delivering a windfall to Australia's big miners and in particular Fortescue. Shareholders were also keen on the company's record annual dividend of $1.14, which included a special dividend of 11??. However, the extraordinary run experienced by Fortescue is less likely to be repeated in 2020 as iron ore prices experienced the steepest monthly decline in more than eight years in September as US-China trade wars and a slow-down in growth weighs on Chinese steel-making demand. And as global supply returns to normal as Vale resumes production in Brazil.

Xero, up 94 per cent to $83.23

Shares in accounting platform Xero almost doubled in value over the course of 2019 starting the year at $42.02 and ending at $83.23. Led by chief executive Steve Vamos, the company capitalised on the move of many small business owners to its cloud-based accounting platforms. It booked a 32 per cent increase in half-yearly revenue at $338.7 million in November. Xero made a modest profit after tax of $1.3 million but Mr Vamos said Xero's focus was on "reinvesting for growth". The Kiwi-founded company's dominance is expected to continue, as Xero hit the two-million subscriber mark late in 2019. Investor John Hempton described the company as "growing like a weed" as it focused on expansion in the United Kingdom and United States. Xero ended the year with a change of chairman with former Telstra chief executive David Thodey set to take over from Graham Smith who is set to step down due to family health issues.

Afterpay, up 135 per cent to $29.20

Afterpay's eventful 2019 saw its share price rocket upwards despite uncertainty over an Austrac-directed audit of its anti-money laundering compliance. The buy-now, pay-later darling rounded the year out with good news: the audit found no solid evidence the millennial-focused payments platform was being used for money laundering. The company told investors in December it had hit $1 billion in monthly sales and has reported solid growth in the US and UK markets. However, there are still some voices urging caution: UBS has taken the most bearish view of the stock so far, after it initiated coverage of the stock in October with a sell recommendation and a target price of $17.60.

Appen, up 82 per cent to $23.37

This artificial intelligence (AI) company got as high as $31.42 this year, thereby cementing itself as a key Australian export with "crowdsource" contractors feeding big tech platforms information to improve machine-based learning functionality. This member of the tech-group known as 'WAAAX' posted strong numbers throughout the year including a number of profit upgrades, but it lost share price momentum in August when half year results raised questions over whether it overpaid when buying San Francisco AI startup Figure Eight. Appen rounded out the year with renewed share price traction after analysts at Bell Potter upgraded the stock to a buy, saying it was "puzzling" that the share price hadn't recovered since the middle of the year and adding a target price of $27.50

JB Hi-Fi, up 80 per cent to $39.82

Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi was the first retailer to report full-year results against a backdrop of negative sentiment that had some investors bracing for the worst. But yet again, chief executive Richard Murray proved he and his team know how to retail, posting a 6.5 per cent increase in earnings. While Murray has remained confident on his business' ability to execute on the "basics of retail" amid a difficult market, his outlook for the rest of the financial year is one of cautious optimism, believing consumers still aren't raring to spend. Nevertheless, the company remains on the front foot, looking at new small-format stores to tap into retail locations such as airports, and continuing to expand its product offering in key categories. The amount of JB Hi-Fi shares held in a short position has fallen from 17.9 per cent at the start of 2019 down to 11.7 per cent. The one dark spot on the business' record is its Good Guys home appliances business.

Aristocrat Leisure up 59 per cent to $34.63

Slot machine giant Aristocrat Leisure delivered a jackpot for investors this year as its pokies business in the United States delivered earnings growth and the online computer game division became a revenue powerhouse. The group grew normalised full-year profit by 22 per cent to $752 million - about 3 per cent higher expected. Revenue from Aristocrat's North American pokies business grew 23 per cent to $1.9 billion, while profit jumped 25 per cent to $1 billion. Aristocrat's portfolio of online video games including War of Clans and RAID: Shadow League brought in almost as much revenue ($1.7 billion, up 33 per cent), but less profit ($529 million). However the company says the games division will become more profitable as new titles reach a critical mass of players and it can trim a hefty marketing bill. A strengthening balance sheet has investors hopeful of buybacks.

CSL, up 52 per cent to $282.29

Investors can thank a global shortage of immunoglobulin for pushing Melbourne-headquartered biotech CSL's shares to record highs this year. The group's market value soared to $129 billion - making it the second largest company on the ASX, behind Commonwealth Bank. Immunoglobulin (or IG) is one of the proteins the company extracts from donors' blood plasma that can be used to treat rare and deadly immunodeficiency and auto-immune diseases. Demand for IG has been growing and CSL is already the world's largest producer. The stock is trading on a high price-to-earnings multiple, but true believers say that's justified by its earnings growth - up 55 per cent over the past five years to $2.7 billion. All eyes will be on a heart-attack prevention human trial in 2020.

Goodman Group, up 29 per cent to $13.71

Industrial giant Goodman has topped its real estate investment trust peers as one of the best performers for the 2019 year, thanks to the booming e-commerce sector. While warehouses were once the ugly duckling of the corporate real estate sector, they are now sought-after fulfilment centres, and Goodman Group is purely focused on industrial real estate. As a result Goodman topped the annual BDO REIT survey based on an overall return of 55.8 per cent - more than double the return on the previous year. BDO's national leader for Real Estate and Construction, Sebastian Stevens, said the performance of the Industrial REITs was driven by the value of high-quality assets in urban corridors which command strong rents."Online shopping continues to fuel demand for fulfilment centres for retailers. They want well located distribution centres to efficiently service their shops and customers. This has been good news for REITs such as Goodman and is resulting in a surge in speculative industrial development," Mr Stevens said. CEO Greg Goodman has forecast a strong 2020 and earnings per security are expected to be 56.3 cents in 2019-20, up 9 per cent on FY19.

Woolies and Coles, up 33 per cent to $37.37 and $15.25 respectively

The 33 per cent rise in Australia's major supermarkets' share price can be in part attributed to small brightly-coloured plastic things. In 2019, Coles and Woolworths both realised collectables were a surefire way to boost sales and foster loyalty. It helped both stores post strong like-for-like sales in each quarter, with Woolworths' growing a record 6.6 per cent for the first quarter of 2020 and Coles' staying positive despite broad expectations of a drop. But the supermarkets' success stretches beyond gimmicky marketing tools. As one of Australia's largest retailers, Woolworths attracted investors as a safe bet in an unpredictable landscape. Similarly, investors interest in Coles was piqued after its successful de-merger from Wesfarmers last year, with the $15 stock under half the price of its competitor and chief executive Steven Cain on a $1 billion cost-cutting warpath. With price wars at a ceasefire (for now), both supermarkets are looking towards online and service as ways to bolster market share. However, as German hypermarket Kaufland is set to arrive next year, they could find themselves under a new wave of pressure in 2020.

Qantas, up 26 pc to $7.33

The flying kangaroo ended the year near all-time highs as investors gained confidence the airline can generate stable earnings in a slowing economy. Qantas' domestic network, the backbone of the company's earnings, faces only tepid competition from Virgin Australia, which is pulling back capacity and focusing more on leisure travel in an effort to stem its losses. Qantas' international arm has been helped by foreign carriers facing higher oil prices and pulling capacity out of Australia for the first time in close to a decade. Meanwhile, earnings continue to grow in the group's loyalty business, which now offers everything from health insurance to credit cards, acting as a buffer to the perpetually volatile airline business.

Domino's Pizza, up 33 per cent to $54.10

Just like a fresh pizza pie, Domino's shares have risen throughout 2019, regardless of the company's falling local profit and franchisee concerns over its ???fortressing' strategy. But shareholder enthusiasm for the discount pizza slinger isn't based on its 825 Australian stores, with the lion's share of revenue and profit growth coming from its nascent Japanese and European network. Earnings for those regions were up 32.1 per cent and 5.5 per cent respectively, with chief executive Don Meij imploring investors to look abroad at its full-year results in August. "If you're an investor in our business, north of 80 per cent of profit growth will come from international markets," he said. However, its controversial ???fortressing' strategy - where the company adjusts the delivery boundaries of existing Domino's stores to allow for new stores - has gotten off to a slow start. Total sales for the first quarter of 2020 actually fell compared to last year, though same-store sales increased. Domino's still maintains guidance of 3-6 per cent same-store growth and a 7-9 per cent increase in store footprint over the next 3-5 years.

Losers

Costa Group, down 61 per cent to $2.53

2019 was a tough year for Costa Group, which describes itself as "Australia's largest grower, packer and marketer of fresh fruit and vegetables". While Costa ends the year an industry heavyweight, its stock price is far lighter than 12 months ago. What happened is that the year started off bad for Costa, with a January announcement of a profit downgrade, and then got worse. Events culminated with a $176 million capital raising announced in late October to pay down debt, as the company cited the impact of drought, high water prices, and smaller harvests from key crops on its financial performance. All up, the company has issued four profit warnings in calendar 2019. For Costa, the challenges over the past 12-15 months have been many. It has had to contend with "crumbly" raspberries which reduced yields from its raspberry crops and led to a substantial replanting program, low prices for mushrooms, and extreme dry conditions that affected the size and yield of major crops like avocados, blueberries, and the late-season citrus crop.

Pilbara Minerals, down 64 per cent to 26??

Pilbara Minerals is one of Australia's biggest producers of lithium and its share price was at $1.18 in early 2018. When 2019 started lithium was still highly popular, having tripled in price since 2010, as it is a key ingredient in the rechargeable batteries that power electric vehicles, computers, mobile phones, and energy storage. However, the rush to mine lithium saw too many producers bring too much volume too quickly, and the Chinese uptake of electric vehicles has been slower than many predicted. All this undermined demand, sending the price of lithium derived from Australian hard-rock plunging 40 per cent. Pilbara Minerals' stock price plunged to a three-year low by December. It has now delayed expanding it Pilgangoora lithium-tantalum project citing market conditions. While few dispute the long-term prospects for lithium alongside the electric vehicle revolution, this year has been a tough one for producers with one mine being placed into the hands of administrators and other operators, including Pilbara Minerals, scaling back production.

Blackmores, down 29 per cent to $86.45

"We're too fat, we're too bureaucratic, we're too complex and we don't make decisions quick enough. And we have to address those things," Marcus Blackmore told The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald back in May. It was refreshing candour from a business leader dealing with a challenging year for the vitamins maker. At the time Mr Blackmore was the interim chief executive of the company founded by his father Maurice, following the resignation in February of former chief executive Richard Henfrey. Blackmores was one of the first stocks on the ASX to surpass $200, back in late 2015, and started 2019 above $120. But investors have since watched the stock fall as low as $63.64 in August, as the market absorbed a series of announcements. This included the CEO's sudden departure in February, a long-running search for its next CEO, the resignation of the boss of its Australian and New Zealand operations in May, and a 24 per cent fall in full year net profit to $53 million. Changes in Chinese e-commerce laws reduced China sales by 15 per cent. Some bright news emerged in July, when Blackmores announced the appointment of Alastair Symington as its next CEO. Blackmores shares ended the year at $86.45, which was 29 per cent lower than 2018, but above the depths plumbed in August.

Big four banks,

The big four banks have generally lagged the wider market in 2019, against a backdrop of slow credit growth, costly customer refunds, and low interest rates. However, some have performed better than others. The country's largest bank Commonwealth Bank has been the standout of the majors, avoiding the falls of rivals Westpac, ANZ Bank and National Australia Bank in the latest quarter. This slump happened as Westpac, NAB and ANZ each reported soft profits in the year to September. Their outlook for the year ahead was not much better, even as the property market improves. The weakness was compounded in November by the explosive money-laundering lawsuit lodged against Westpac, which sparked a dramatic resignation from former CEO Brian Hartzer, and a pledge by chairman Lindsay Maxsted to step down early. Further weighing on the share price, Westpac had cut its dividend and raised capital earlier that month. There are fears NAB has its own money laundering compliance problems lurking, and it has acknowledged it is talking with the financial intelligence agency, AUSTRAC. ANZ has said it has no material issues with AUSTRAC, but its chairman David Gonski has also said he can't promise there won't be any surprises.

Chief investment officer at Atlas Funds Management, Hugh Dive, points out that CBA settled its lawsuit from AUSTRAC last year with a $700 million penalty, and its September quarter profit was well-received by the market.

"CBA had a relatively good quarter. They've already had their AUSTRAC fine," Mr Dive said.

While the profits of banks have been soft, however, the sector's share prices did receive a boost this year from the royal commission's final report in February being less tough than feared, and the re-election of the Morrison government.

Outside the big four, a particularly weak performer has been Bank of Queensland, whose shares have fallen 22 per cent since the start of the year. The regional bank has had a tough year, posting disappointing profits, cutting its dividend, and warning of a weaker bottom line result next year. The bank's new chief executive, former Westpac banker George Frazis, also tapped shareholders for another $275 million in equity capital.

All share prices are until December 24.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XV8-K2J1-DY19-C22D-00000-002019 delivers surprises and surprising returns2019-12-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:54ZLexisNexis2019 delivers surprises and surprising returnsLucy Battersby

Australia's stock market increased more than 20 per cent in 2019 and hit all-time highs, despite deep uncertainty.

Australia's stock market reached new historical highs during 2019 even though it was missing a key ingredient usually required for financial success - certainty.

Waves of surprises kept coming in the forms of interest rate cuts, a surprise Coalition election victory, aggressive overnight tweets from US President Donald Trump and the resultant Chinese currency retaliation, mass demonstrations and short seller attacks.

Despite all this, the S&P/ASX 200 managed to close 20 per cent higher at 6794 points over the year to December 24. Despite a weakening economy, many household names reached prices well above anyone's expectations. Fortescue, Wesfarmers, CSL, Qantas, and JB Hi-Fi all ended the year in uncharted territory.

The investment director at Bennelong Australian Equity Partners, Julian Beaumont, says the past twelve months held a lot of surprises.

"Fair to say that 2019 was a better year than most would have ever expected. If you were able to predict the uncertainty hanging over markets from the trade-war, Brexit, Hong Kong riots, weaker than expected global and domestic growth, and poor corporate earnings, then you wouldn't probably have predicted a strong market.

"And it really just goes to show that whatever is happening politically, socially, and on a macro front, aren't necessarily the drivers of stock market returns. Ultimately the biggest driver of returns this year was interest rates and their precipitous fall."

The lower interest rate environment boosts other asset prices. So while stock prices might be more expensive than ever before, this is not because companies are performing better than ever before.

"Over-valuation has to be put in context. And right now when you consider where interest rates are, where housing yields are, where property cap rates are, then in that context equity is actually probably rationally priced. From the point of view of earnings and dividend yield they are actually quite attractive versus the [other asset classes].''

IFM's outgoing chief executive Brett Himbury said the current investment climate was the toughest he has seen since the early 1980s due to low interest rates, geopolitical volatility in advanced markets, the rise of "burdensome" regulation, and levels of trust in financial services being at an "all-time low".

"Most governments, except Australia, are really fiscally constrained. They've got an enormous amount of debt so they've got very little strategic flexibility to generate growth,'' he said.

Unusually, advanced markets have more geopolitical risk than emerging markets currently, he says, which makes it very tough for investors.

"You put all these things together and I honestly think it's the toughest environment we've seen since 1982. I don't envy the job of chief investment officers trying to allocate, whether they're going to go to Australia or not, hedge or not hedge, cash and fixed interest or listed equities."

So what were the best, worst, and most interesting performances of 2019?

Winners

Fortescue, up 184 per cent to $10.91

The iron-ore pure play had the biggest gains of the S&P/ASX200 during 2019, rising from $3.80 to $10.91. The company has been surfing a boom in iron ore prices driven by extremely strong demand from Chinese steel mills and global supply constraints after a fatal dam collapse at an iron ore mine in Brazil. Iron ore prices hit $US120 per tonne early in 2019, delivering a windfall to Australia's big miners and in particular Fortescue. Shareholders were also keen on the company's record annual dividend of $1.14, which included a special dividend of 11??. However, the extraordinary run experienced by Fortescue is less likely to be repeated in 2020 as iron ore prices experienced the steepest monthly decline in more than eight years in September as US-China trade wars and a slow-down in growth weighs on Chinese steel-making demand. And as global supply returns to normal as Vale resumes production in Brazil.

Xero, up 94 per cent to $83.23

Shares in accounting platform Xero almost doubled in value over the course of 2019 starting the year at $42.02 and ending at $83.23. Led by chief executive Steve Vamos, the company capitalised on the move of many small business owners to its cloud-based accounting platforms. It booked a 32 per cent increase in half-yearly revenue at $338.7 million in November. Xero made a modest profit after tax of $1.3 million but Mr Vamos said Xero's focus was on "reinvesting for growth". The Kiwi-founded company's dominance is expected to continue, as Xero hit the two-million subscriber mark late in 2019. Investor John Hempton described the company as "growing like a weed" as it focused on expansion in the United Kingdom and United States. Xero ended the year with a change of chairman with former Telstra chief executive David Thodey set to take over from Graham Smith who is set to step down due to family health issues.

Afterpay, up 135 per cent to $29.20

Afterpay's eventful 2019 saw its share price rocket upwards despite uncertainty over an Austrac-directed audit of its anti-money laundering compliance. The buy-now, pay-later darling rounded the year out with good news: the audit found no solid evidence the millennial-focused payments platform was being used for money laundering. The company told investors in December it had hit $1 billion in monthly sales and has reported solid growth in the US and UK markets. However, there are still some voices urging caution: UBS has taken the most bearish view of the stock so far, after it initiated coverage of the stock in October with a sell recommendation and a target price of $17.60.

Appen, up 82 per cent to $23.37

This artificial intelligence (AI) company got as high as $31.42 this year, thereby cementing itself as a key Australian export with "crowdsource" contractors feeding big tech platforms information to improve machine-based learning functionality. This member of the tech-group known as 'WAAAX' posted strong numbers throughout the year including a number of profit upgrades, but it lost share price momentum in August when half year results raised questions over whether it overpaid when buying San Francisco AI startup Figure Eight. Appen rounded out the year with renewed share price traction after analysts at Bell Potter upgraded the stock to a buy, saying it was "puzzling" that the share price hadn't recovered since the middle of the year and adding a target price of $27.50

JB Hi-Fi, up 80 per cent to $39.82

Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi was the first retailer to report full-year results against a backdrop of negative sentiment that had some investors bracing for the worst. But yet again, chief executive Richard Murray proved he and his team know how to retail, posting a 6.5 per cent increase in earnings. While Murray has remained confident on his business' ability to execute on the "basics of retail" amid a difficult market, his outlook for the rest of the financial year is one of cautious optimism, believing consumers still aren't raring to spend. Nevertheless, the company remains on the front foot, looking at new small-format stores to tap into retail locations such as airports, and continuing to expand its product offering in key categories. The amount of JB Hi-Fi shares held in a short position has fallen from 17.9 per cent at the start of 2019 down to 11.7 per cent. The one dark spot on the business' record is its Good Guys home appliances business.

Aristocrat Leisure up 59 per cent to $34.63

Slot machine giant Aristocrat Leisure delivered a jackpot for investors this year as its pokies business in the United States delivered earnings growth and the online computer game division became a revenue powerhouse. The group grew normalised full-year profit by 22 per cent to $752 million - about 3 per cent higher expected. Revenue from Aristocrat's North American pokies business grew 23 per cent to $1.9 billion, while profit jumped 25 per cent to $1 billion. Aristocrat's portfolio of online video games including War of Clans and RAID: Shadow League brought in almost as much revenue ($1.7 billion, up 33 per cent), but less profit ($529 million). However the company says the games division will become more profitable as new titles reach a critical mass of players and it can trim a hefty marketing bill. A strengthening balance sheet has investors hopeful of buybacks.

CSL, up 52 per cent to $282.29

Investors can thank a global shortage of immunoglobulin for pushing Melbourne-headquartered biotech CSL's shares to record highs this year. The group's market value soared to $129 billion - making it the second largest company on the ASX, behind Commonwealth Bank. Immunoglobulin (or IG) is one of the proteins the company extracts from donors' blood plasma that can be used to treat rare and deadly immunodeficiency and auto-immune diseases. Demand for IG has been growing and CSL is already the world's largest producer. The stock is trading on a high price-to-earnings multiple, but true believers say that's justified by its earnings growth - up 55 per cent over the past five years to $2.7 billion. All eyes will be on a heart-attack prevention human trial in 2020.

Goodman Group, up 29 per cent to $13.71

Industrial giant Goodman has topped its real estate investment trust peers as one of the best performers for the 2019 year, thanks to the booming e-commerce sector. While warehouses were once the ugly duckling of the corporate real estate sector, they are now sought-after fulfilment centres, and Goodman Group is purely focused on industrial real estate. As a result Goodman topped the annual BDO REIT survey based on an overall return of 55.8 per cent - more than double the return on the previous year. BDO's national leader for Real Estate and Construction, Sebastian Stevens, said the performance of the Industrial REITs was driven by the value of high-quality assets in urban corridors which command strong rents."Online shopping continues to fuel demand for fulfilment centres for retailers. They want well located distribution centres to efficiently service their shops and customers. This has been good news for REITs such as Goodman and is resulting in a surge in speculative industrial development," Mr Stevens said. CEO Greg Goodman has forecast a strong 2020 and earnings per security are expected to be 56.3 cents in 2019-20, up 9 per cent on FY19.

Woolies and Coles, up 33 per cent to $37.37 and $15.25 respectively

The 33 per cent rise in Australia's major supermarkets' share price can be in part attributed to small brightly-coloured plastic things. In 2019, Coles and Woolworths both realised collectables were a surefire way to boost sales and foster loyalty. It helped both stores post strong like-for-like sales in each quarter, with Woolworths' growing a record 6.6 per cent for the first quarter of 2020 and Coles' staying positive despite broad expectations of a drop. But the supermarkets' success stretches beyond gimmicky marketing tools. As one of Australia's largest retailers, Woolworths attracted investors as a safe bet in an unpredictable landscape. Similarly, investors interest in Coles was piqued after its successful de-merger from Wesfarmers last year, with the $15 stock under half the price of its competitor and chief executive Steven Cain on a $1 billion cost-cutting warpath. With price wars at a ceasefire (for now), both supermarkets are looking towards online and service as ways to bolster market share. However, as German hypermarket Kaufland is set to arrive next year, they could find themselves under a new wave of pressure in 2020.

Qantas, up 26 pc to $7.33

The flying kangaroo ended the year near all-time highs as investors gained confidence the airline can generate stable earnings in a slowing economy. Qantas' domestic network, the backbone of the company's earnings, faces only tepid competition from Virgin Australia, which is pulling back capacity and focusing more on leisure travel in an effort to stem its losses. Qantas' international arm has been helped by foreign carriers facing higher oil prices and pulling capacity out of Australia for the first time in close to a decade. Meanwhile, earnings continue to grow in the group's loyalty business, which now offers everything from health insurance to credit cards, acting as a buffer to the perpetually volatile airline business.

Domino's Pizza, up 33 per cent to $54.10

Just like a fresh pizza pie, Domino's shares have risen throughout 2019, regardless of the company's falling local profit and franchisee concerns over its ???fortressing' strategy. But shareholder enthusiasm for the discount pizza slinger isn't based on its 825 Australian stores, with the lion's share of revenue and profit growth coming from its nascent Japanese and European network. Earnings for those regions were up 32.1 per cent and 5.5 per cent respectively, with chief executive Don Meij imploring investors to look abroad at its full-year results in August. "If you're an investor in our business, north of 80 per cent of profit growth will come from international markets," he said. However, its controversial ???fortressing' strategy - where the company adjusts the delivery boundaries of existing Domino's stores to allow for new stores - has gotten off to a slow start. Total sales for the first quarter of 2020 actually fell compared to last year, though same-store sales increased. Domino's still maintains guidance of 3-6 per cent same-store growth and a 7-9 per cent increase in store footprint over the next 3-5 years.

Losers

Costa Group, down 61 per cent to $2.53

2019 was a tough year for Costa Group, which describes itself as "Australia's largest grower, packer and marketer of fresh fruit and vegetables". While Costa ends the year an industry heavyweight, its stock price is far lighter than 12 months ago. What happened is that the year started off bad for Costa, with a January announcement of a profit downgrade, and then got worse. Events culminated with a $176 million capital raising announced in late October to pay down debt, as the company cited the impact of drought, high water prices, and smaller harvests from key crops on its financial performance. All up, the company has issued four profit warnings in calendar 2019. For Costa, the challenges over the past 12-15 months have been many. It has had to contend with "crumbly" raspberries which reduced yields from its raspberry crops and led to a substantial replanting program, low prices for mushrooms, and extreme dry conditions that affected the size and yield of major crops like avocados, blueberries, and the late-season citrus crop.

Pilbara Minerals, down 64 per cent to 26??

Pilbara Minerals is one of Australia's biggest producers of lithium and its share price was at $1.18 in early 2018. When 2019 started lithium was still highly popular, having tripled in price since 2010, as it is a key ingredient in the rechargeable batteries that power electric vehicles, computers, mobile phones, and energy storage. However, the rush to mine lithium saw too many producers bring too much volume too quickly, and the Chinese uptake of electric vehicles has been slower than many predicted. All this undermined demand, sending the price of lithium derived from Australian hard-rock plunging 40 per cent. Pilbara Minerals' stock price plunged to a three-year low by December. It has now delayed expanding it Pilgangoora lithium-tantalum project citing market conditions. While few dispute the long-term prospects for lithium alongside the electric vehicle revolution, this year has been a tough one for producers with one mine being placed into the hands of administrators and other operators, including Pilbara Minerals, scaling back production.

Blackmores, down 29 per cent to $86.45

"We're too fat, we're too bureaucratic, we're too complex and we don't make decisions quick enough. And we have to address those things," Marcus Blackmore told The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald back in May. It was refreshing candour from a business leader dealing with a challenging year for the vitamins maker. At the time Mr Blackmore was the interim chief executive of the company founded by his father Maurice, following the resignation in February of former chief executive Richard Henfrey. Blackmores was one of the first stocks on the ASX to surpass $200, back in late 2015, and started 2019 above $120. But investors have since watched the stock fall as low as $63.64 in August, as the market absorbed a series of announcements. This included the CEO's sudden departure in February, a long-running search for its next CEO, the resignation of the boss of its Australian and New Zealand operations in May, and a 24 per cent fall in full year net profit to $53 million. Changes in Chinese e-commerce laws reduced China sales by 15 per cent. Some bright news emerged in July, when Blackmores announced the appointment of Alastair Symington as its next CEO. Blackmores shares ended the year at $86.45, which was 29 per cent lower than 2018, but above the depths plumbed in August.

Big four banks,

The big four banks have generally lagged the wider market in 2019, against a backdrop of slow credit growth, costly customer refunds, and low interest rates. However, some have performed better than others. The country's largest bank Commonwealth Bank has been the standout of the majors, avoiding the falls of rivals Westpac, ANZ Bank and National Australia Bank in the latest quarter. This slump happened as Westpac, NAB and ANZ each reported soft profits in the year to September. Their outlook for the year ahead was not much better, even as the property market improves. The weakness was compounded in November by the explosive money-laundering lawsuit lodged against Westpac, which sparked a dramatic resignation from former CEO Brian Hartzer, and a pledge by chairman Lindsay Maxsted to step down early. Further weighing on the share price, Westpac had cut its dividend and raised capital earlier that month. There are fears NAB has its own money laundering compliance problems lurking, and it has acknowledged it is talking with the financial intelligence agency, AUSTRAC. ANZ has said it has no material issues with AUSTRAC, but its chairman David Gonski has also said he can't promise there won't be any surprises.

Chief investment officer at Atlas Funds Management, Hugh Dive, points out that CBA settled its lawsuit from AUSTRAC last year with a $700 million penalty, and its September quarter profit was well-received by the market.

"CBA had a relatively good quarter. They've already had their AUSTRAC fine," Mr Dive said.

While the profits of banks have been soft, however, the sector's share prices did receive a boost this year from the royal commission's final report in February being less tough than feared, and the re-election of the Morrison government.

Outside the big four, a particularly weak performer has been Bank of Queensland, whose shares have fallen 22 per cent since the start of the year. The regional bank has had a tough year, posting disappointing profits, cutting its dividend, and warning of a weaker bottom line result next year. The bank's new chief executive, former Westpac banker George Frazis, also tapped shareholders for another $275 million in equity capital.

All share prices are until December 24.

Contributors: Charlotte Grieve, Dominic Powell, Cara Waters, Emma Koehn, Darren Gray, Nick Toscano, Patrick Hatch, Carolyn Cummins, and Clancy Yeates.

The Kiwi-founded company's dominance is expected to continue, as Xero hit the two-million subscriber mark late in 2019. Investor John Hempton described the company as "growing like a weed" as it focused on expansion in the United Kingdom and United States. Xero ended the year with a change of chairman with former Telstra chief executive David Thodey set to take over from Graham Smith who is set to step down due to family health issues.

Afterpay, up 135 per cent to $29.20

Afterpay's eventful 2019 saw its share price rocket upwards despite uncertainty over an Austrac-directed audit of its anti-money laundering compliance. The buy-now, pay-later darling rounded the year out with good news: the audit found no solid evidence the millennial-focused payments platform was being used for money laundering. The company told investors in December it had hit $1 billion in monthly sales and has reported solid growth in the US and UK markets. However, there are still some voices urging caution: UBS has taken the most bearish view of the stock so far, after it initiated coverage of the stock in October with a sell recommendation and a target price of $17.60.

Appen, up 82 per cent to $23.37

This artificial intelligence (AI) company got as high as $31.42 this year, thereby cementing itself as a key Australian export with "crowdsource" contractors feeding big tech platforms information to improve machine-based learning functionality. This member of the tech-group known as 'WAAAX' posted strong numbers throughout the year including a number of profit upgrades, but it lost share price momentum in August when half year results raised questions over whether it overpaid when buying San Francisco AI startup Figure Eight. Appen rounded out the year with renewed share price traction after analysts at Bell Potter upgraded the stock to a buy, saying it was "puzzling" that the share price hadn't recovered since the middle of the year and adding a target price of $27.50

JB Hi-Fi, up 80 per cent to $39.82

Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi was the first retailer to report full-year results against a backdrop of negative sentiment that had some investors bracing for the worst. But yet again, chief executive Richard Murray proved he and his team know how to retail, posting a 6.5 per cent increase in earnings. While Murray has remained confident on his business' ability to execute on the "basics of retail" amid a difficult market, his outlook for the rest of the financial year is one of cautious optimism, believing consumers still aren't raring to spend. Nevertheless, the company remains on the front foot, looking at new small-format stores to tap into retail locations such as airports, and continuing to expand its product offering in key categories. The amount of JB Hi-Fi shares held in a short position has fallen from 17.9 per cent at the start of 2019 down to 11.7 per cent. The one dark spot on the business' record is its Good Guys home appliances business.

Aristocrat Leisure up 59 per cent to $34.63

Slot machine giant Aristocrat Leisure delivered a jackpot for investors this year as its pokies business in the United States delivered earnings growth and the online computer game division became a revenue powerhouse. The group grew normalised full-year profit by 22 per cent to $752 million - about 3 per cent higher expected. Revenue from Aristocrat's North American pokies business grew 23 per cent to $1.9 billion, while profit jumped 25 per cent to $1 billion. Aristocrat's portfolio of online video games including War of Clans and RAID: Shadow League brought in almost as much revenue ($1.7 billion, up 33 per cent), but less profit ($529 million). However the company says the games division will become more profitable as new titles reach a critical mass of players and it can trim a hefty marketing bill. A strengthening balance sheet has investors hopeful of buybacks.

CSL, up 52 per cent to $282.29

Investors can thank a global shortage of immunoglobulin for pushing Melbourne-headquartered biotech CSL's shares to record highs this year. The group's market value soared to $129 billion - making it the second largest company on the ASX, behind Commonwealth Bank. Immunoglobulin (or IG) is one of the proteins the company extracts from donors' blood plasma that can be used to treat rare and deadly immunodeficiency and auto-immune diseases. Demand for IG has been growing and CSL is already the world's largest producer. The stock is trading on a high price-to-earnings multiple, but true believers say that's justified by its earnings growth - up 55 per cent over the past five years to $2.7 billion. All eyes will be on a heart-attack prevention human trial in 2020.

Goodman Group, up 29 per cent to $13.71

Industrial giant Goodman has topped its real estate investment trust peers as one of the best performers for the 2019 year, thanks to the booming e-commerce sector. While warehouses were once the ugly duckling of the corporate real estate sector, they are now sought-after fulfilment centres, and Goodman Group is purely focused on industrial real estate. As a result Goodman topped the annual BDO REIT survey based on an overall return of 55.8 per cent - more than double the return on the previous year. BDO's national leader for Real Estate and Construction, Sebastian Stevens, said the performance of the Industrial REITs was driven by the value of high-quality assets in urban corridors which command strong rents."Online shopping continues to fuel demand for fulfilment centres for retailers. They want well located distribution centres to efficiently service their shops and customers. This has been good news for REITs such as Goodman and is resulting in a surge in speculative industrial development," Mr Stevens said. CEO Greg Goodman has forecast a strong 2020 and earnings per security are expected to be 56.3 cents in 2019-20, up 9 per cent on FY19.

Woolies and Coles, up 33 per cent to $37.37 and $15.25 respectively

The 33 per cent rise in Australia's major supermarkets' share price can be in part attributed to small brightly-coloured plastic things. In 2019, Coles and Woolworths both realised collectables were a surefire way to boost sales and foster loyalty. It helped both stores post strong like-for-like sales in each quarter, with Woolworths' growing a record 6.6 per cent for the first quarter of 2020 and Coles' staying positive despite broad expectations of a drop. But the supermarkets' success stretches beyond gimmicky marketing tools. As one of Australia's largest retailers, Woolworths attracted investors as a safe bet in an unpredictable landscape. Similarly, investors interest in Coles was piqued after its successful de-merger from Wesfarmers last year, with the $15 stock under half the price of its competitor and chief executive Steven Cain on a $1 billion cost-cutting warpath. With price wars at a ceasefire (for now), both supermarkets are looking towards online and service as ways to bolster market share. However, as German hypermarket Kaufland is set to arrive next year, they could find themselves under a new wave of pressure in 2020.

Qantas, up 26 pc to $7.33

The flying kangaroo ended the year near all-time highs as investors gained confidence the airline can generate stable earnings in a slowing economy. Qantas' domestic network, the backbone of the company's earnings, faces only tepid competition from Virgin Australia, which is pulling back capacity and focusing more on leisure travel in an effort to stem its losses. Qantas' international arm has been helped by foreign carriers facing higher oil prices and pulling capacity out of Australia for the first time in close to a decade. Meanwhile, earnings continue to grow in the group's loyalty business, which now offers everything from health insurance to credit cards, acting as a buffer to the perpetually volatile airline business.

Domino's Pizza, up 33 per cent to $54.10

Just like a fresh pizza pie, Domino's shares have risen throughout 2019, regardless of the company's falling local profit and franchisee concerns over its ???fortressing' strategy. But shareholder enthusiasm for the discount pizza slinger isn't based on its 825 Australian stores, with the lion's share of revenue and profit growth coming from its nascent Japanese and European network. Earnings for those regions were up 32.1 per cent and 5.5 per cent respectively, with chief executive Don Meij imploring investors to look abroad at its full-year results in August. "If you're an investor in our business, north of 80 per cent of profit growth will come from international markets," he said. However, its controversial ???fortressing' strategy - where the company adjusts the delivery boundaries of existing Domino's stores to allow for new stores - has gotten off to a slow start. Total sales for the first quarter of 2020 actually fell compared to last year, though same-store sales increased. Domino's still maintains guidance of 3-6 per cent same-store growth and a 7-9 per cent increase in store footprint over the next 3-5 years.

Losers

Costa Group, down 61 per cent to $2.53

2019 was a tough year for Costa Group, which describes itself as "Australia's largest grower, packer and marketer of fresh fruit and vegetables". While Costa ends the year an industry heavyweight, its stock price is far lighter than 12 months ago. What happened is that the year started off bad for Costa, with a January announcement of a profit downgrade, and then got worse. Events culminated with a $176 million capital raising announced in late October to pay down debt, as the company cited the impact of drought, high water prices, and smaller harvests from key crops on its financial performance. All up, the company has issued four profit warnings in calendar 2019. For Costa, the challenges over the past 12-15 months have been many. It has had to contend with "crumbly" raspberries which reduced yields from its raspberry crops and led to a substantial replanting program, low prices for mushrooms, and extreme dry conditions that affected the size and yield of major crops like avocados, blueberries, and the late-season citrus crop.

Pilbara Minerals, down 64 per cent to 26??

Pilbara Minerals is one of Australia's biggest producers of lithium and its share price was at $1.18 in early 2018. When 2019 started lithium was still highly popular, having tripled in price since 2010, as it is a key ingredient in the rechargeable batteries that power electric vehicles, computers, mobile phones, and energy storage. However, the rush to mine lithium saw too many producers bring too much volume too quickly, and the Chinese uptake of electric vehicles has been slower than many predicted. All this undermined demand, sending the price of lithium derived from Australian hard-rock plunging 40 per cent. Pilbara Minerals' stock price plunged to a three-year low by December. It has now delayed expanding it Pilgangoora lithium-tantalum project citing market conditions. While few dispute the long-term prospects for lithium alongside the electric vehicle revolution, this year has been a tough one for producers with one mine being placed into the hands of administrators and other operators, including Pilbara Minerals, scaling back production.

Blackmores, down 29 per cent to $86.45

"We're too fat, we're too bureaucratic, we're too complex and we don't make decisions quick enough. And we have to address those things," Marcus Blackmore told The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald back in May. It was refreshing candour from a business leader dealing with a challenging year for the vitamins maker. At the time Mr Blackmore was the interim chief executive of the company founded by his father Maurice, following the resignation in February of former chief executive Richard Henfrey. Blackmores was one of the first stocks on the ASX to surpass $200, back in late 2015, and started 2019 above $120. But investors have since watched the stock fall as low as $63.64 in August, as the market absorbed a series of announcements. This included the CEO's sudden departure in February, a long-running search for its next CEO, the resignation of the boss of its Australian and New Zealand operations in May, and a 24 per cent fall in full year net profit to $53 million. Changes in Chinese e-commerce laws reduced China sales by 15 per cent. Some bright news emerged in July, when Blackmores announced the appointment of Alastair Symington as its next CEO. Blackmores shares ended the year at $86.45, which was 29 per cent lower than 2018, but above the depths plumbed in August.

Big four banks,

The big four banks have generally lagged the wider market in 2019, against a backdrop of slow credit growth, costly customer refunds, and low interest rates. However, some have performed better than others. The country's largest bank Commonwealth Bank has been the standout of the majors, avoiding the falls of rivals Westpac, ANZ Bank and National Australia Bank in the latest quarter. This slump happened as Westpac, NAB and ANZ each reported soft profits in the year to September. Their outlook for the year ahead was not much better, even as the property market improves. The weakness was compounded in November by the explosive money-laundering lawsuit lodged against Westpac, which sparked a dramatic resignation from former CEO Brian Hartzer, and a pledge by chairman Lindsay Maxsted to step down early. Further weighing on the share price, Westpac had cut its dividend and raised capital earlier that month. There are fears NAB has its own money laundering compliance problems lurking, and it has acknowledged it is talking with the financial intelligence agency, AUSTRAC. ANZ has said it has no material issues with AUSTRAC, but its chairman David Gonski has also said he can't promise there won't be any surprises.

Chief investment officer at Atlas Funds Management, Hugh Dive, points out that CBA settled its lawsuit from AUSTRAC last year with a $700 million penalty, and its September quarter profit was well-received by the market.

"CBA had a relatively good quarter. They've already had their AUSTRAC fine," Mr Dive said.

While the profits of banks have been soft, however, the sector's share prices did receive a boost this year from the royal commission's final report in February being less tough than feared, and the re-election of the Morrison government.

Outside the big four, a particularly weak performer has been Bank of Queensland, whose shares have fallen 22 per cent since the start of the year. The regional bank has had a tough year, posting disappointing profits, cutting its dividend, and warning of a weaker bottom line result next year. The bank's new chief executive, former Westpac banker George Frazis, also tapped shareholders for another $275 million in equity capital.

All share prices are until December 24.

Contributors: Charlotte Grieve, Dominic Powell, Cara Waters, Emma Koehn, Darren Gray, Nick Toscano, Patrick Hatch, Carolyn Cummins, and Clancy Yeates.
